The poverty rate for Hispanic households also reflects this disparity, standing at 23.6% in 2014—substantially higher than the 14.8% poverty rate for all U.S. households ![{Poverty rate disparity between Hispanic and all U.S. households}(image2)]. Despite some improvements since the peak of 26.5% in 2010, the rate remains above pre-recession levels.

In terms of wealth, Hispanic households experienced a significant decline in net worth, with a median wealth of $13,700 in 2013, compared to $81,400 for all U.S. households ![{Median household wealth disparity between Hispanic and all U.S. households}(image2)]. This illustrates a long-standing challenge in building and maintaining financial assets.

Overall, while there have been some positive trends, such as increased optimism about personal finances and economic conditions, Hispanic households continue to face greater economic challenges than the broader U.S. population in key areas like unemployment, income, poverty, and wealth.

The perception of personal financial situations and family income relative to the cost of living among Latino groups has shown a notable improvement from 2008 to 2015. According to [1], an analysis of survey data reveals that Latino perceptions of their economic well-being have increased among most major Latino demographic subgroups. This trend is further supported by [7] and [8], which indicate that ratings of personal finances improve among most Latino groups, with significant gains observed across various subgroups.

In terms of family income relative to the cost of living, [3] highlights that in 2015, about half (53%) of Latinos said their family income was not keeping up with the cost of living, while 10% felt it was going up faster than the cost of living. ![{Latino perceptions of family income relative to cost of living in 2014 and 2015}](image1) illustrates that in both years, approximately half of Hispanic adults felt their income was falling behind, showing relatively stable trends over time.

Looking at broader demographic comparisons, [2] notes that whites also reported some improvement in their family income relative to the cost of living, resulting in similar views across racial and ethnic groups in 2015. However, [9] emphasizes that Latino views of their financial situation are more positive now than they were in 2004, when roughly a third (31%) rated their financial condition as excellent or good, compared to about half (51%) of the general public in 2004.

![{Trends in financial perceptions for Hispanics and the general public from 2004 to 2015}](image2) shows a decline in positive financial perceptions for both groups during the period roughly between 2008 and 2010, followed by an increase in 2015. This aligns with [10], which reports that positive views of economic well-being rose significantly among various Latino subgroups, including those born in another country, U.S.-born Hispanics, and different education levels.

Additionally, [6] points out that about half (48%) of Latinos aged 18 to 29 reported being in excellent or good financial shape in 2015, representing a 27 percentage point increase from 2008. ![{Changes in support or approval among various demographic groups from 2008 to 2015}](image3) supports this by showing a general increase in support or approval among all groups, with the age group 18-29 experiencing the most significant rise.

Overall, perceptions of personal financial situations and family income relative to the cost of living among Latino groups have improved significantly from 2008 to 2015.

Text quotes [5] and [6] indicate that internet use and broadband adoption among seniors fall off notably starting at approximately age 75, with younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors using the internet and broadband at rates approaching—or even exceeding—the general population. Additionally, affluent and well-educated seniors adopt the internet and broadband at substantially higher rates than those with lower levels of income and educational attainment [7].  

![{Internet usage and broadband adoption among seniors compared to all adults}](image5)  

Text quote [8] highlights that although seniors are less likely than the rest of the population to go online in the first place, once there they tend to make the internet a part of their daily routine. Among seniors who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and 11% go online three to five times per week. The subset of seniors who have a smartphone or a home broadband connection go online with even greater frequency: 78% of older broadband users go online every day or almost every day, as do 84% of older smartphone owners.  

![{Percentage of internet users in different age groups who go online}](image1)  

Text quote [2] reveals that smartphone ownership is fairly low along the entire age spectrum of the older adult population, but decreases substantially for seniors in their mid-70s (λ₁₀% of 75-79 year olds own a smartphone), and becomes nearly non-existent among seniors in their 80s and beyond (just 5% of those 80 and older are smartphone owners).  

![{Smartphone and tablet/e-reader ownership among all adults and those aged 65+}](image3)  

Text quote [10] notes that device ownership among older adults differs notably from the population as a whole in several specific ways.  

![{Percentage of technology adoption between "All adults" and those aged "65+"}](image5)  

Text quote [4] states that most seniors who become internet users make visiting the digital world a regular occurrence. Among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online every day or almost every day, and an additional 11% go online three to five times per week.  

The data shows that internet usage and device ownership among seniors vary significantly compared to all adults, with notable declines in adoption and usage as age increases, particularly after 75 years. However, once seniors adopt technology, they tend to integrate it into their daily routines.

Text quotes [2] and [9] directly address the differences in device ownership among older adults compared to the general population. Additionally, text quote [5] highlights that while 77% of older adults own a cell phone, most of these are basic devices, and only 18% own a smartphone. This is contrasted with the general population, where smartphone ownership is significantly higher.  

Text quote [10] indicates that among older adults who use the internet, 71% go online daily or almost every day, showing a strong correlation between internet usage and regular engagement with digital platforms. This aligns with image2, which illustrates the frequency of internet use across different age groups, including seniors. ![Internet Usage Frequency](image2)  

Moreover, text quote [1] and [8] provide insights into social networking site (SNS) usage among older adults, noting that 27% of older adults use SNS, which is lower than the national average. However, those who do use SNS tend to socialize more frequently compared to non-users.

In summary, while older adults show increasing internet usage and device ownership, they still lag behind the general population in terms of smartphone adoption and broadband access. The patterns of internet use among seniors are characterized by frequent daily engagement, though their overall adoption rates remain below the national average.

The difference in device ownership between seniors and the general adult population is notable. For instance, only 18% of seniors own a smartphone, which is significantly lower than the national adoption rate of 55% [3]. Additionally, 27% of seniors own a tablet or e-book reader, compared to 43% of all adults [3]. These statistics are visually represented in ![{device ownership among seniors vs. all adults}](image3), highlighting the disparity in device adoption.

Online activity also shows a gap. Six in ten seniors—59%—report using the internet, which is a six percentage point increase from 2012 [4]. However, this still trails behind the 86% of all U.S. adults who go online. The table in ![{percentage of people aged 65 and older who go online and have broadband at home}](image1) provides detailed data on how online usage varies by age, education, and household income, showing that those 80 years or older have the lowest rates of internet use and broadband adoption.

Trends over time reveal significant growth in internet adoption for seniors. In May 2008, just 35% of seniors were internet users, but this has increased to 59% today [4]. Similarly, broadband adoption among seniors has more than doubled since 2008, rising from 19% to 47% [9]. These trends are illustrated in ![{internet adoption trends over time for seniors and all adults}](image4), where both groups show upward trends, though seniors lag behind the general population.

![{categories of online usage}](image2) further illustrates that while 27% of seniors use social networking sites, these users tend to maintain more persistent social connections. Overall, the data indicates that while seniors are increasingly adopting digital technologies, there remains a significant gap compared to the general adult population, with certain subgroups being more digitally engaged than others. 

The differences in device ownership and online activity between seniors and the general adult population are evident, with seniors generally lagging behind in adoption rates, although there are notable increases over time.

The adoption of devices among seniors shows a notable trend, with tablets and e-book readers being more commonly owned than smartphones. ![{Seniors own more tablets and e-readers than smartphones}](image1) This is reflected in the data where 27% of seniors own a tablet or e-book reader, compared to 18% who own a smartphone. 

In contrast, the usage of online social networking sites (SNS) among seniors is lower but still significant. According to [2], 59% of seniors report using the internet, and 46% of these online seniors use social networking sites such as Facebook. Furthermore, [7] highlights that 27% of older adults use SNS, and these users tend to maintain more frequent social connections. 

While the percentage of seniors using SNS is lower than the general population's internet usage rate, it indicates a growing engagement with digital platforms for social interaction. ![{Online usage and social networking habits among seniors}](image2) The pie chart illustrates that 27% of seniors use SNS, showing a clear distinction from those who do not go online or use the internet without social networking.

Overall, device ownership trends among seniors show a preference for tablets and e-book readers, while their online social networking usage, though lower than the general population, is increasing and plays a crucial role in maintaining social connections. Seniors who use SNS are more likely to engage in persistent social interactions, highlighting the importance of these platforms in their daily lives. 

The comparison between device ownership and online social networking usage reveals that while seniors may not be as prevalent in using SNS as the general population, they are increasingly adopting technologies that support social connectivity.

Internet and broadband adoption rates among older adults show significant variation based on age, education, and income. For instance, **younger, higher-income, and more highly educated seniors** use the internet and broadband at rates approaching—or even exceeding—the general population [3]. In contrast, **those 80 years of age or older, those with low household incomes, and those who have not attended college** tend to be much more removed from online life [10]. 

![{senior internet adoption by age income and education}](image5)  
The table highlights that **65-69-year-olds** have the highest rates of going online (74%) and broadband adoption (65%), while **80+ seniors** lag significantly, with only 37% going online and 21% having broadband at home. Similarly, **college graduates** have higher adoption rates than those with lower educational attainment, with 87% going online and 76% having broadband.

![{senior smartphone adoption by age income and education}](image3)  
Smartphone adoption is also influenced by these factors. While **75% of seniors** own cell phones, only **18%** own smartphones. The adoption rate declines sharply with age, with **only 5% of those 80+** owning smartphones. Higher income and education levels correlate with higher smartphone ownership, such as **42% of seniors with a household income over $75,000** owning smartphones.

![{senior e-book and tablet usage by age income and education}](image1)  
E-book reader and tablet computer usage also vary by age, education, and income. **College graduates** are more likely to use these devices, with **30% using e-book readers** and **31% using tablets**, compared to **12% and 11%** for those with only a high school diploma. Income also plays a role, with **33% of seniors earning $75,000+** using e-book readers, versus **8%** for those earning less than $30,000.

In comparison to the general adult population, **86% of all U.S. adults** go online, whereas only **59% of seniors** do so [2]. Broadband adoption among seniors has more than doubled since 2008, reaching **47%** in the general population, but still lags behind [6].

Overall, internet and broadband adoption rates among seniors are steadily increasing but remain well below the national average, with disparities based on age, education, and income.

The adoption rates of internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones among seniors vary significantly based on income and education levels. For instance, seniors with higher incomes and college degrees are more likely to adopt these technologies. ![{Seniors with higher income and education have higher adoption rates}](image3) shows that college graduates have a 87% online usage rate and 76% broadband adoption, while those with less education have lower rates. Similarly, seniors earning $75,000 or more have 90% online usage and 82% broadband adoption, compared to only 39% online and 25% broadband for those earning less than $30,000 annually [9].

Cell phone ownership is also influenced by these factors. ![{Higher income and education correlate with higher cell phone ownership}](image5) indicates that seniors with higher incomes and education levels have greater cell phone ownership. For example, 92% of seniors earning $75,000 or more own a cell phone, whereas only 67% of those earning less than $30,000 do. College graduates also show higher cell phone ownership at 87%, compared to 70% for those with less education.

Smartphone adoption follows a similar pattern. ![{Smartphone adoption varies with income and education}](image1) reveals that 18% of seniors own a smartphone, which is much lower than the national average of 55%. However, this rate increases with higher income and education. For example, 42% of seniors earning $75,000 or more own a smartphone, compared to just 8% of those earning less than $30,000 annually. College graduates also have a higher smartphone adoption rate at 35%, compared to 10% for those with less education.

Overall, seniors with higher income and education levels demonstrate significantly higher adoption rates for internet, broadband, cell phones, and smartphones compared to their lower-income and less-educated counterparts.

For "Enthusiastic," 6% are "Very" enthusiastic, 27% are "Somewhat" enthusiastic, 47% are "Not too" enthusiastic, and 20% are "Not at all" enthusiastic. For "Worried," 25% are "Very" worried, 48% are "Somewhat" worried, 23% are "Not too" worried, and 4% are "Not at all" worried.

Regarding expected outcomes from widespread automation, [1] and [8] reveal that most Americans expect more negative than positive outcomes. Specifically, around three-quarters (76%) of Americans expect increased inequality between rich and poor if machines can do many human jobs, while only 25% think the economy will create many new, better-paying jobs for humans. [4] and [10] also emphasize that the public generally expects more negative outcomes, with 76% anticipating much greater economic inequality and nearly two-thirds expecting people will have a hard time finding things to do with their lives.

![{Outcomes of Automation}](image4)  
This image presents survey responses on possible outcomes of automation. For negative outcomes, 76% believe inequality between rich and poor will be much worse than today, and 64% think people will have a hard time finding things to do with their lives. For positive outcomes, only 25% expect the economy to create many new, better-paying jobs, and 43% believe the economy as a whole will be much more efficient.

In summary, Americans' awareness about automation affects their views, with higher awareness correlating with more enthusiasm but not less worry, and they generally expect more negative outcomes from widespread automation.

The public opinion on workforce automation policies shows notable differences between Democrats and Republicans. Democrats are more supportive of policies such as a universal basic income and a national service program, with 77% of Democrats favoring a universal basic income compared to just 38% of Republicans [2]. Similarly, support for a national service program is higher among Democrats at 66% versus 46% among Republicans [2]. However, there is broad agreement across party lines on the importance of limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, with 85% of Americans in favor of this policy [6].

![{Public strongly supports limiting robots to dangerous jobs}](image1)  
The image highlights that a significant majority of the public supports limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, indicating a strong consensus on this issue.

While there are partisan differences in support for certain policies, the general level of support for limiting machines to dangerous jobs remains high, with 85% of Americans favoring this approach [6]. This reflects a widespread recognition of the need to protect human workers from hazardous tasks through automation.

[1] Political affiliations significantly influence opinions on government obligations and automation limits. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of policies like universal basic income and national service programs, with 77% favoring a guaranteed income compared to 38% of Republicans [2]. Similarly, support for limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs is broadly shared across parties, but there are notable differences in views on government responsibility for displaced workers. Democrats are more likely to believe the government should take care of displaced workers, even if it means higher taxes, while Republicans lean toward individual responsibility [3].

![{government obligation}](image4)  
![{automation limits}](image4)

[6] Educational levels also shape opinions on these issues. Americans with lower educational attainment are more supportive of limiting how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines, with 70% of those with high school diplomas or less favoring such limits, compared to 41% of college graduates [10]. However, educational differences do not significantly affect views on whether the government has an obligation to support displaced workers, as both groups show similar levels of support for this idea [9].

[8] A strong majority of Americans—85%—favor policies that limit robots and computers to doing dangerous or unhealthy jobs, indicating broad public support for such measures regardless of political or educational background [8]. This aligns with findings from image1, where 47% strongly favor this policy, making it the most supported among the four topics examined.

![{policy support}](image1)  
![{partisan support}](image2)

[7] Despite partisan differences, there is notable alignment on the question of whether businesses should be limited in replacing human jobs with machines. Over half of Republicans (54%) and a slightly higher percentage of Democrats (60%) support such limits, suggesting that while political affiliations shape opinions, there is a shared recognition of the need for some form of regulation [7].

In summary, political affiliations and education levels both play roles in shaping opinions on government obligations and automation limits related to job displacement, with Democrats generally showing stronger support for government intervention and lower educational attainment correlating with greater support for limiting automation.

Text quotes [1] and [10] highlight the significant partisan divide in American views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement. Democrats and Democratic-leaning independents are more supportive of a universal basic income (77% vs. 38% of Republicans) and a national service program (66% vs. 46%) in the event that machines replace a large share of human jobs. Additionally, there is strong bipartisan support for limiting machines to dangerous and dirty jobs, as well as allowing people to pay extra to interact with humans rather than robots in commercial transactions.

![{bipartisan support for limiting automation to dangerous jobs}](image2)  
The image illustrates that a majority of Americans, regardless of political affiliation, favor limiting machines to dangerous or unhealthy jobs, showing a level of agreement across party lines.

Quote [4] further emphasizes these partisan differences by noting that 65% of Democrats feel the government has an obligation to take care of displaced workers, while 68% of Republicans believe individuals should be responsible for their own financial well-being. This reflects a broader ideological divide between the two parties on the role of government in addressing job displacement caused by automation.

![{partisan views on government responsibility for displaced workers}](image3)  
This image breaks down public opinion on whether the government or individuals should be responsible for displaced workers, clearly showing a stark partisan split.

Quote [6] reveals that despite these divisions, there is notable alignment on the question of whether businesses should be limited in how many human jobs they can replace with machines. Over half of both Republicans (54%) and Democrats (60%) support such limits, indicating a shared concern about the impact of automation on employment.

![{support for limiting job replacement by businesses}](image4)  
The image highlights the support among Democrats and Republicans for imposing limits on how many human jobs businesses can replace with machines, demonstrating a surprising degree of consensus.

Finally, quote [5] mentions educational divisions alongside partisan ones, suggesting that factors beyond political affiliation also influence opinions on automation-related policies. For instance, those with lower levels of education are more likely to favor a universal basic income, as noted in quote [7].

In summary, political affiliations significantly affect American views on policies related to workforce automation and job displacement, with Democrats generally more supportive of government intervention and guaranteed income programs, while Republicans tend to emphasize individual responsibility and market forces.

Workers’ attitudes towards workforce automation and the perceived impact of technology vary significantly among different age groups and education levels. For instance, younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 24, are more likely to have been personally impacted by workforce automation, with a higher percentage reporting job loss or pay reduction due to automation [2]. ![{Younger adults are more likely to have been impacted by workforce automation}](image3)  

Regarding education levels, workers with higher educational attainment generally express more positive views of workplace technologies. College graduates are more likely to believe that technology has made their work more interesting and increased their opportunities for career advancement compared to those with only a high school diploma or less [8]. ![{Higher education levels correlate with more positive perceptions of technology}](image4)  

The impact of specific technologies also varies across education levels. Workers with college degrees are substantially more likely than those without to view each of the six common workforce technologies as having a positive impact on their jobs or careers [9]. In contrast, workers lacking a college education are much less likely to express positive attitudes towards these technologies [5].  

Additionally, the survey highlights that while many workers expect their jobs to be impacted by automation, this expectation is more pronounced among those who have already experienced negative effects from automation. Nearly six-in-ten workers who have been impacted by automation anticipate that their jobs will be mostly done by machines within their lifetimes, compared to just over a quarter of those who have not been impacted [6].  

Overall, the data underscores a clear divide in how different age groups and education levels perceive the impact of technology on their work and careers. The most significant differences are observed between those with higher education levels and those with less formal education.

Workers express mixed views about the impact of various workforce technologies, with notable differences across education levels and demographics. For instance, college graduates are more likely to view technology positively, as evidenced by higher percentages indicating that it has made their work more interesting (64% vs. 38% for high school graduates or less) and increased their career advancement opportunities (53% vs. 32%) [1]. This trend is further supported by the fact that workers with higher educational attainment are more likely to perceive a positive impact from technologies such as word processing software, smartphones, and customer self-serve tools [7]. 

![{College graduates are more likely to view technology positively}](image4)

In contrast, workers without a college education are much less likely to express positive attitudes towards current workforce technologies [2]. The survey highlights that the benefits of these technologies are most pronounced for those with higher formal education, while those without college degrees often see them as neutral or even detrimental to their career prospects [4]. 

Moreover, the impact of automation and technology varies significantly across different age groups. For example, younger workers (ages 18-24) are more likely to have experienced job loss or reduced pay due to technological changes compared to older workers [image1]. Similarly, certain professions are more susceptible to automation than others, with roles like fast food workers and insurance claims processors showing a higher likelihood of being affected by automation [image3].

Overall, the data underscores that perceptions of technology's impact are not uniform and are heavily influenced by both education level and demographic factors. Workers with higher education levels tend to benefit more from technological advancements, while those with less education often face challenges and negative perceptions [9]. 

The disparity in how different groups perceive the impact of technology highlights the need for targeted support and training to ensure that all workers can benefit from ongoing technological changes.

Workers' perceptions of job interest and advancement opportunities are significantly influenced by both their education levels and the specific technologies they use. According to the survey, workers with higher levels of education tend to view technology more positively, as evidenced by the data showing that **College Grad+** individuals are more likely to find their work more interesting and to see increased opportunities for career advancement compared to those with lower education levels [2], [6], [7], [8]. 

![{Education level impact on job interest and advancement}](image2)  

For instance, **64%** of College Grad+ workers feel that technology has made their work more interesting, while only **38%** of those with high school diplomas or less share this view. Similarly, **53%** of College Grad+ workers believe technology has increased their chances for advancement, versus **32%** among those with less formal education. This disparity highlights how education can shape one's perspective on the role of technology in the workplace.

![{Perceived impact of technology on job interest}](image1)  

When it comes to specific technologies, the majority of workers report positive impacts, especially with tools like word processing software, smartphones, and email/social media. For example, **70%** of workers say word processing or spreadsheet software has had a positive impact on their careers, while **67%** note the same for smartphones [9]. However, not all technologies are viewed equally; industrial robots, for example, are seen as beneficial by only **27%** of workers, with a larger portion (14%) perceiving them negatively [4], [10].

![{Impact of various technologies on workers}](image4)  

In summary, education levels and specific technologies play a crucial role in shaping workers' perceptions of job interest and advancement opportunities, with higher education generally correlating with more positive views toward technological impacts.

The survey reveals that different age groups react emotionally to social media content in distinct ways, with younger users reporting stronger emotional responses overall. For instance, the youngest age group (18-29) is more likely to feel amused, lonely, and depressed compared to older age groups. Specifically, 54% of users aged 18-29 frequently feel amused, while only 30% of those aged 65 and older report the same [5]. Conversely, older adults experience anger at a similar rate to younger users, with 24% of those aged 65 and older frequently feeling angry, compared to 27% of users aged 18-29 [1]. Younger users also show higher rates of loneliness, with 15% of those aged 18-29 frequently feeling lonely, versus just 4% of those 50 and older [5].

![{Amused and angry emotions across age groups}](image2)  
Across all users, amusement is the most frequently experienced emotion, with 88% of respondents saying they see content on social media that makes them feel amused [7]. This aligns with the finding that 44% of users frequently feel amused by the content they encounter [3]. Anger is also a common emotion, with 25% of users frequently feeling angry due to social media content [6]. However, other emotions like depression and loneliness are more prevalent among younger users, with 17% of those aged 18-29 frequently feeling depressed and 15% feeling lonely [5]. 

![{Emotion frequency across all users}](image3)  
While amusement remains the most frequent emotion, the data also highlights that negative emotions such as anger and loneliness are significant for certain age groups. The survey underscores the varied emotional impact of social media, showing that while amusement is widespread, other emotions vary significantly based on age and individual experiences.

The emotional experiences of social media users vary significantly across different age groups, with younger adults reporting stronger and more frequent emotional responses. For instance, **18-29-year-olds** are more likely than older adults to feel **lonely** (15%) or **depressed** (17%) due to content they encounter on social media [1]. In contrast, **older adults (65+)** are less likely to feel amused (30%) or angry (24%) compared to their younger counterparts [7]. This trend is reflected in a dot plot showing that younger people tend to report stronger emotions across all categories, with the highest percentages for amusement (54%) and loneliness (15%) among 18-29-year-olds [image1].

![{Younger adults experience stronger emotions on social media}](image1)

In addition to these emotional responses, users are frequently exposed to specific types of content. A bar chart highlights that **58%** of users say they often see posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated, while **59%** encounter posts where people make accusations or start arguments without all the facts [5]. These findings indicate that users are regularly exposed to content that can provoke strong reactions.

![{Frequent exposure to dramatic and argumentative content}](image4)

Furthermore, the data reveals that **young adults** are twice as likely to say they frequently see content that makes them feel amused (54%) compared to angry (27%) [7], whereas older adults encounter these two types of content with more comparable frequency (30% amused vs. 24% angry) [1]. This suggests that younger users are more susceptible to positive emotional engagement with social media content, but also more prone to negative emotions like anger and depression.

Overall, the emotional landscape of social media use is shaped by both age and the type of content users are exposed to, with younger individuals experiencing a broader range of emotions and being more influenced by content that elicits amusement or distress.

The Pew Research Center survey highlights significant variations in how different age groups and genders perceive emotional responses and behaviors on social media, as well as the types of content they frequently encounter. 

Younger adults, particularly those aged 18 to 29, are more likely to experience a range of emotions such as loneliness and depression, while older adults report feeling more amused by content they see online. For instance, **15%** of users aged 18 to 29 say they frequently feel lonely, compared to just **4%** of those 50 and older. Conversely, **30%** of users aged 65 and older say they frequently feel amused, whereas only **27%** of young adults report the same. ![{Youth and Older Adults' Emotional Responses on Social Media}](image2)

Gender also plays a role in emotional perception. Men are more likely than women to encounter content that makes them feel angry or to see people being mean or bullying. Specifically, **29%** of men say they more often see people being mean or bullying, compared to **19%** of women. On the other hand, women are more likely to see kind or supportive behavior, with **24%** of women reporting this compared to **17%** of men. ![{Gender Differences in Perceptions of Online Behavior}](image4)

In terms of content types, users frequently encounter posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated (58%) and people making accusations or starting arguments without all the facts (59%). These two categories dominate user experiences, as noted in the survey findings. ![{Common Types of Content on Social Media}](image5)

Additionally, the survey reveals that **54%** of social media users typically see an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior, while **21%** more often see kind behavior and **24%** more often see bullying content. This indicates a complex mix of positive and negative interactions on these platforms.

Overall, younger age groups tend to report stronger emotional reactions, including both positive and negative feelings, while older adults show more consistent emotional responses. Gender differences also emerge, with men more likely to perceive negative behaviors and women more likely to see positive ones. ![{Emotional Responses Across Age Groups}](image2)

The question of how different age groups and genders experience emotions and behaviors on social media, as well as the most common types of posts they encounter, is addressed through a combination of textual insights and visual data. 

For instance, **image1** illustrates the acceptability of various online recommendations, showing that users generally find it more acceptable for social media sites to recommend events in their area than to show them ads from political campaigns. This aligns with [2], which highlights that majorities across age groups feel it is not acceptable for platforms to use their data for political campaign ads.

![{acceptability of online recommendations}](image1)

When it comes to emotional experiences, **image2** provides a clear breakdown of the frequency of different emotions such as anger, amusement, and loneliness. It reveals that anger is experienced frequently by 25% of users and sometimes by 47%, resulting in a net score of 71. This ties into [7], where it is noted that a significant percentage of conservative Republicans frequently feel angry due to content they see on social media.

![{frequency of different emotions}](image2)

Regarding gender differences, **image3** compares perceptions of online behavior between men and women. It shows that men are more likely to perceive people as being mean or bullying compared to women, while women are more likely to see kind or supportive behavior. This finding is supported by [10], which notes that men are slightly more likely than women to encounter harassing or abusive behavior online.

![{perceptions of online behavior by gender}](image3)

In terms of age group differences, **image4** displays how different age groups react emotionally to various content types. Younger users (ages 18-29) tend to report stronger emotional responses across all categories, with higher percentages of amusement and anger compared to older age groups. This observation complements [4] and [5], which highlight the variability in user experiences based on age.

![{emotional responses by age group}](image4)

Finally, **image5** outlines the frequency of different types of posts encountered on social media. Posts that are overly dramatic or exaggerated are seen frequently by 58% of users, while people making accusations without all the facts are also frequently encountered. These findings resonate with [6] and [9], which discuss the prevalence of misleading and exaggerated content on social media platforms.

![{frequency of different types of posts}](image5)

In summary, different age groups and genders experience a range of emotions and encounter various types of behaviors and content on social media, with younger users and men often reporting more intense reactions and exposure to negative or misleading content.

Men and women have distinct perceptions of online behaviors such as bullying, deception, and correcting misinformation. According to the data, men are more likely than women to see people being mean or bullying on social media, with 29% of men reporting this compared to 19% of women [9]. Conversely, women are more likely than men to see people being kind or supportive, with 24% of women reporting this compared to 17% of men [9]. Additionally, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people trying to be deceptive, with 24% of men versus 13% of women [5].

![{Men and women's perceptions of online behaviors}(image1)]  
The image illustrates these differences clearly, showing that while both genders perceive a mix of behaviors, men tend to report higher frequencies of seeing negative behaviors like bullying and deception.

Regarding dramatic or exaggerated posts, the survey found that 58% of users frequently encounter such content [3], and this aligns with the broader perception that users often see overly dramatic or exaggerated posts. This frequency suggests that such content is prevalent and may influence how users perceive the overall tone and nature of interactions on social media, potentially affecting their views on behaviors like deception and misinformation correction.

Users’ perceptions of social media content and behavior differ significantly between men and women, as shown in the data. Men are more likely than women to see people being mean or bullying on social media platforms, with 29% of men reporting this compared to 19% of women [4]. Conversely, women are slightly more likely than men to see people being kind or supportive, with 24% of women reporting this versus 17% of men [4]. However, a majority of both men (58%) and women (67%) perceive an equal mix of supportive and bullying behavior on social media [4].

Additionally, men are around twice as likely as women to say they more often see people being deceptive on social media (24% vs. 13%) [10]. Despite these differences, both genders largely agree that there is an equal mix of deceptiveness and attempts to correct misinformation, with 63% of users overall perceiving this balance [10].

![{Men and women perceptions of online behavior}(image2)]  

These gender-based differences in perception have implications for how social media platforms can tailor their recommendations or advertisements. For instance, younger age groups (18-29) show higher acceptance of data usage for recommending events in their area and for showing ads for products or services, while older age groups (65+) are less accepting of such uses [image1]. Similarly, the acceptability of different types of content varies, with some categories like political campaign messages being viewed less favorably across all age groups [image5].

Given that men are more likely to perceive negative behaviors, platforms may need to consider adjusting their content moderation strategies or providing clearer context to reduce perceived negativity. On the other hand, since women are more inclined to see positive interactions, emphasizing community-building features or supportive content could enhance user experience and engagement. Ultimately, understanding these nuances allows platforms to better align their content and advertising strategies with user expectations and comfort levels.

Users’ perceptions of the acceptability of social media platforms using their data vary significantly across age groups and depend heavily on the context in which the data are used. For instance, **[9]** highlights that across age groups, users are generally comfortable with their data being used to recommend events but are more wary of it being used for political messaging. This is further supported by **[1]**, which states that a $75\%$ majority of users are comfortable with their data being used to recommend events they might like, but this drops to just $37\%$ when the data are used for political campaigns.

![{Users' comfort with data usage for different purposes}(image1)]  
This image illustrates how different age groups perceive the acceptability of various data uses. It shows that younger users (ages 18-29) are more likely to approve of recommendations for events in their area compared to older users (ages 65+). However, when it comes to recommending people they might want to know, there is a notable divide, with younger users more accepting than older ones.

Similarly, **[4]** indicates that three-quarters of users find it acceptable for platforms to use their data to recommend events in their area, while only $57\%$ think it is acceptable for their data to be used to recommend other people they might want to be friends with. This aligns with **[6]**, which notes that younger users are more open to data being used for connecting with others, while older users are less accepting.

![{Acceptability of different online recommendations}(image2)]  
This bar chart provides a detailed breakdown of how users rate the acceptability of different types of recommendations. It shows that for all categories, a significant portion of users consider these practices somewhat or very acceptable, though acceptance varies. Notably, political messages receive the lowest approval, with only $7\%$ of users finding them very acceptable.

In addition, **[5]** emphasizes that users are somewhat less comfortable with data being used for advertisements, with around half ($52\%$) finding it acceptable, but a similar share ($47\%$) finding it not acceptable. The disparity between those who find it very acceptable ($11\%$) and those who find it not at all acceptable ($21\%$) underscores the mixed feelings toward this practice.

Overall, user comfort with social media platforms using their data is highly context-dependent, as noted in **[7]** and **[8]**. Users tend to be more accepting of data usage for personal convenience (like event recommendations) but less so for politically motivated content or targeted advertising. This perception is influenced by both age and the specific purpose of data collection, with younger users generally showing greater tolerance for data-driven interactions.

The public's perception of fairness and effectiveness varies significantly across different automated systems used for decision-making, reflecting broader concerns about bias, privacy, and the ethical implications of algorithmic decision-making. For instance, the personal finance score concept is viewed as less fair compared to its effectiveness, with only 32% of Americans believing it would be fair to consumers, while 54% think it would be effective at identifying good customers [1]. This 22-percentage-point gap highlights a notable lack of trust in the fairness of such systems, even when they are perceived as effective [3].

![{perceived fairness and effectiveness comparison}](image3)  
The chart illustrates this disparity clearly, showing that the personal finance score has the largest effective-fair difference, indicating significant skepticism about its fairness despite its perceived effectiveness.

In contrast, the criminal risk score, which is used to determine parole eligibility, is seen as more fair, with 50% of Americans thinking it would be fair to those up for parole, slightly outperforming its effectiveness rating of 49% [1]. This close alignment between effectiveness and fairness suggests a more balanced view, though still not reaching a majority.

![{fairness perceptions across scenarios}](image4)  
The bar chart further emphasizes these differences, showing that the criminal risk score is perceived as somewhat fair by 41%, while the personal finance score is considered somewhat fair by only 27%. This indicates a strong preference for systems that are perceived as fair, particularly in contexts where the stakes are high, such as parole decisions.

Demographic variations also play a role, with racial and ethnic groups expressing differing levels of concern. For example, Blacks are more likely than whites to find the consumer finance score fair, but they express greater concern about the criminal risk score [3]. These disparities suggest that public trust in automated systems may be influenced by factors beyond just the system's functionality, including historical and social contexts.

Moreover, the general public is skeptical about the fairness of these programs, with none viewed as fair by a clear majority [7]. The video job interview analysis algorithm, for instance, is seen as even less fair, with only 33% of Americans believing it would be fair to job applicants, despite being perceived as effective by 39% [9]. This mismatch underscores a deep-seated concern about the potential for these systems to perpetuate bias or unfair treatment.

![{acceptability of personal finance score}](image2)  
The bar chart on acceptability reinforces these findings, showing that 68% of Americans find the personal finance score algorithm unacceptable, citing reasons such as privacy violations and unfairness. This widespread rejection implies a lack of public trust in the ethical use of such algorithms, especially when they impact individuals' financial lives.

Overall, the differences in perceptions of fairness and effectiveness across various automated systems highlight a complex landscape of public trust. While some systems are viewed as more effective, they often fall short in terms of fairness, leading to skepticism and resistance. These findings suggest that building public trust in algorithmic decision-making will require not only demonstrating effectiveness but also addressing concerns about bias, transparency, and the ethical implications of these technologies.

The public's perception of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness has been consistently lower than that of previous presidents, with significant differences observed across political affiliations. According to [1], views of the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials remain at record lows compared to previous administrations dating back to the 1980s. Similarly, [4] highlights that only 39% rate the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials as excellent or good, while 59% say they are not good or poor—lower than evaluations for presidents from Reagan onwards.

Trust in Trump's statements is also notably lower than trust in previous presidents. [9] states that a majority of the public (58%) says they trust what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said, with only 26% trusting him more and 14% finding his rhetoric about the same as past presidents. This trend is further supported by [2], which notes that 94% of Democrats and Democratic leaners say they trust what Trump says less than they trusted what previous presidents said.

![{public distrust in Trump compared to previous presidents}](image4)  
Among Republicans and Republican leaners, [6] reveals that most (58%) say they trust what Trump says more than previous presidents, while 25% say they trust his statements about the same as previous presidents, and 15% say they trust his rhetoric less. In contrast, [10] shows that 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners believe that the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are not good or poor, with 67% rating them as "poor."

![{partisan differences in trust and ethical standards}](image2)  
The divide between political affiliations is stark, as illustrated by [10], where 76% of Republicans and Republican leaners view the ethical standards of top administration officials as excellent or good, while 90% of Democrats and Democratic leaners hold the opposite view. This partisan gap underscores the deepening polarization in perceptions of Trump's leadership and ethical conduct.

In summary, perceptions of Trump's ethical standards and trustworthiness are significantly lower than those of previous presidents, particularly among Democrats, while Republicans tend to have more favorable views.

The public perception of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness shows significant differences compared to previous presidents, with strong partisan divides. A majority of the public, 58%, believes Trump has a responsibility to release his tax returns, reflecting a broader expectation for transparency [3]. This aligns with the general sentiment that Trump should be held accountable, as seen in the image showing that Democrats and Democratic leaners overwhelmingly support this view, while Republicans are more divided [image3].

Trust in Trump's statements is notably lower than in previous presidents, with 58% of the public trusting what Trump says less than they trusted past presidents [10]. This distrust has increased since 2017, further highlighting a growing gap in public confidence [7]. However, among Republicans and Republican leaners, most (58%) say they trust Trump more than previous presidents, indicating a stark contrast in partisan perspectives [8].

Public perceptions of Trump's economic impact reveal a mixed picture. While 40% believe his policies have improved economic conditions, 28% think they have worsened it, and 29% say there has been little effect [1]. These views are reflected in the image showing that Republican-leaning individuals are more likely to see positive economic outcomes, whereas Democratic-leaning individuals are more critical [image4].

Comparing Trump's approval ratings to those of previous presidents, the image illustrates that public opinion on his success is less optimistic than for leaders like Obama or Bush [image2]. Overall, these findings underscore the polarized nature of public perception, where partisan affiliation significantly influences views on Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness. 

![{Public trust in Trump compared to previous presidents}](image3)  
![{Economic impact perceptions}](image4)  
![{Trust in Trump's statements}](image1)  

Public perceptions of Trump's responsibilities and trustworthiness are more negative than those of previous presidents, with strong partisan differences.

The perception of Trump's presidency varies significantly among political affiliations, particularly in terms of trust, ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success. ![{Partisan views on Trump’s economic policies}](image2) Democrats and Democratic leaners generally hold more negative views compared to Republicans and Republican leaners. For instance, 94% of Democrats and Democratic leaners believe the ethical standards of top Trump administration officials are not good or poor, while only 16% of Republicans and Republican leaners think they are excellent [10]. This stark divide reflects deep partisan polarization.

Regarding economic impact, there is a notable difference in opinions between Republicans and Democrats. In January 2019, 79% of Republicans and Republican leaners believed Trump's economic policies had improved conditions, whereas only 10% of Democrats and Democratic leaners held this view [9]. Additionally, the share of the public who said Trump's economic policies had not had much of an effect declined from 49% in October 2017 to 29% in January 2019 [8], indicating a growing belief in positive economic outcomes among Republicans.

When it comes to long-term success, Republicans and Republican leaners are more optimistic, with 65% believing Trump will be a successful president in the long run, while 47% think he will be unsuccessful [3]. This contrasts sharply with Democrats and Democratic leaners, where 80% believe Trump will be unsuccessful [10]. These views align with historical patterns; for example, in December 2003, 69% of Republicans thought George W. Bush would be successful, similar to current sentiments about Trump [6].

![{Public opinion on long-term presidential success}](image3) The image illustrates that public opinion on long-term success for Trump is more negative than for previous presidents like Obama and George W. Bush at comparable points in their administrations. For instance, in February 1995, 34% of the public thought Bill Clinton would be unsuccessful, compared to 47% for Trump [5]. This suggests a more unfavorable assessment of Trump's legacy compared to past leaders.

Overall, perceptions of Trump's presidency are highly polarized, with significant differences in trust, ethical standards, economic impact, and long-term success among political affiliations. These perceptions also show a more negative outlook for Trump compared to previous presidents, especially when viewed through the lens of partisan divides.

Among party affiliates, perceptions of Trump's presidency show stark contrasts compared to those of Obama, Bush, and Clinton. For instance, **Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** are significantly more likely to view Trump as successful, with 65% expressing this view, while only 7% of Democrats and Democratic leaners hold the same opinion [1]. Conversely, **Democrats and Democratic leaners** overwhelmingly believe Trump will be unsuccessful, with 80% holding this view, compared to just 3% of Republicans [5].

These partisan divides mirror historical patterns seen with previous presidents. For example, during the early years of their presidencies, similar levels of partisanship were observed. In 2003, **69% of Republicans** thought George W. Bush would be successful, while **3%** believed he would be unsuccessful, a pattern that closely resembles current views of Trump [10]. Similarly, in 2011, **43% of Democrats** thought Barack Obama would be successful, whereas **47%** said it was too early to tell, highlighting how partisanship has shaped opinions over time [4].

![{Partisan perceptions of presidential success at different points in their presidencies}](image1)

The trend of **low expectations for Trump’s legacy** is also notable. About half (47%) of Americans think Trump will be an unsuccessful president, which is much higher than the shares who held similar views about his three most recent predecessors at comparable points in their first terms [9]. This reflects a broader shift in public sentiment, where **Republicans’ views of Trump’s long-term outlook** are more optimistic than those of Democrats, even when considering historical comparisons [6].

In addition to these partisan differences, there has been a noticeable **polarization in economic policy views** since 2017. Nearly 80% of Republicans and Republican leaners believe Trump’s economic policies have improved conditions, up from 63% in October 2017, while Democrats have grown increasingly negative toward these policies [8]. This polarization underscores how public opinion on Trump’s policies has become more divided over time.

![{Opinions on whether Trump's policies made things better or worse}](image2)

Overall, the data suggests that **public opinion on Trump’s presidency is deeply polarized**, with strong partisan divisions shaping perceptions of his success and impact. Over time, these trends reflect both historical patterns and evolving political sentiments among different groups.

The perception of Trump's potential success as a president shows a stark divide between Republican and Democratic respondents. According to the data, **65% of Republicans and Republican-leaning independents** believe Trump will be a successful president in the long run, while **80% of Democrats and Democratic leaners** think he will be unsuccessful [6], [3]. This contrast is further emphasized by comparisons to previous presidents, such as George W. Bush in his third year, where **69% of Republicans** thought Bush would be successful, compared to **37% of Democrats** who believed he would be unsuccessful [2]. 

![{Republicans' views on Trump's success are similar to how they viewed Bush in his third year}(image3)]  

These differing perceptions are closely tied to levels of confidence in the Mueller investigation. **Democrats** exhibit significantly higher confidence in the fairness of the investigation, with **72%** expressing at least some confidence, while **58% of Republicans** express doubt [7]. Overall, **55%** of the public says they are very or somewhat confident in Mueller’s investigation, with **41%** expressing lack of confidence [8]. The partisan divide is evident, as **92% of Democrats** lack confidence in Trump’s handling of matters related to the investigation, whereas **75% of Republicans** express confidence [9]. 

![{Confidence in Mueller's investigation is deeply divided along party lines}(image2)]  

In summary, perceptions of Trump's potential success as a president are highly polarized, with Republicans generally more optimistic and Democrats more pessimistic, and these views align closely with levels of confidence in the Mueller investigation.

The perception of economic conditions and job availability shows a clear partisan divide, with Republicans generally expressing more optimism than Democrats. However, the perception of “good jobs” remains less optimistic, with a notable gap between political affiliations. For example, **58% of Republicans** believe good jobs are widely available, whereas **39% of Democrats** share this view [3]. ![{perceptions of jobs and good jobs}](image3)  

Over time, the partisan divide has remained consistent, with Republicans consistently reporting higher levels of optimism about job availability. Image5 highlights this trend, showing that support for Republicans/Lean Republicans reached **71% in 2019**, while Democrats/Lean Democrats stood at **53%** [5].  

Despite these differences, there is a general upward trend in overall job availability perceptions across all groups, indicating a positive shift in public sentiment regarding the job market.  

The perception of economic conditions and job availability differs between political affiliations, with Republicans generally more optimistic, and the overall trend shows increasing optimism over time.

The public's views on Wall Street’s impact on the economy are clearly divided along political lines. Republicans and Republican leaners tend to be more positive, with 55% believing Wall Street helps the economy more than it hurts, compared to only 31% who think it hurts [1]. In contrast, Democrats and Democratic leaners are more divided, with 46% saying Wall Street hurts the economy more than it helps and 41% saying it helps [7]. This divergence is further emphasized by the general trend that Republicans are more likely to view Wall Street positively, while Democrats are more evenly split [8].

![{Republicans more likely to say Wall Street helps U.S. economy; Democrats are more divided on impact}](image3)  

Satisfaction levels with the nation’s condition have also shown a significant decline over the years. As of the latest data, 70% of Americans are dissatisfied with the way things are going in the country, up from 54% in 1990, as illustrated by the line graph showing a steady increase in dissatisfaction [image1]. This dissatisfaction is even more pronounced among Democrats, with no more than 16% expressing satisfaction during Trump’s presidency, and just 8% currently satisfied [10]. Meanwhile, Republicans have seen a sharp drop in satisfaction, with 47% now dissatisfied, down from 59% in September [9].

The overall dissatisfaction with the nation's state has increased by 9 percentage points since September, reaching its highest level in the past year [5]. This growing discontent is reflected across all political affiliations, though Democrats express it more strongly than Republicans.

![{The image is a line graph showing the percentages of people who are "Dissatisfied" and "Satisfied" with the way things are going in the country from 1990 to 2019.}](image1)  

Public opinions on Wall Street and national satisfaction both reflect deepening partisan divides, with Republicans generally more optimistic about the economy and more satisfied with national conditions, while Democrats show greater pessimism and division.

Public dissatisfaction with the state of the nation has steadily increased over the years, as illustrated by the line graph in image2, which shows that dissatisfaction rose from 54% in 1990 to 70% by 2019, while satisfaction dropped from 41% to 26%. Bush’s presidency, Republican support peaked at 56%, but this declined under Clinton and later surged again during G.W. Bush’s term before tapering off. However, these opinions are not evenly distributed across political lines. Republicans/Lean Republicans (Rep/Lean Rep) are more likely to view Wall Street positively, with 55% believing it helps the economy more than it hurts, compared to only 31% who think it hurts. On the other hand, Democrats/Lean Democrats (Dem/Lean Dem) are more divided, with 46% believing Wall Street hurts the economy more than it helps, and 41% thinking it helps more.  

This division highlights how party affiliation influences perceptions of Wall Street’s role in the economy, even as overall public dissatisfaction with national conditions continues to rise. The interplay between these trends suggests that political polarization and economic concerns remain significant factors in shaping public opinion.

The public's confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly higher among Republicans compared to Democrats. According to the data, **64% of Republicans/Lean Republicans** are very confident in this area, while only **2% of Democrats/Lean Democrats** express similar confidence. This stark contrast is evident in the bar chart comparing confidence levels between the two groups [3]. 

![{Confidence in making good appointments to the federal courts}](image3)  

This confidence level in judicial appointments is part of a broader pattern where Republicans show much higher confidence in Trump's abilities across various tasks. For instance, **51% of Republicans** are very or somewhat confident in Trump’s ability to negotiate favorable trade agreements, compared to just **3% of Democrats** [1]. Similarly, **52% of Republicans** are very or somewhat confident in Trump’s ability to manage the executive branch effectively, whereas **2% of Democrats** hold this view [9].

However, there are notable differences in confidence across tasks. While Republicans are generally more confident in Trump's economic policy decisions and trade negotiations, they rate him lower on working effectively with Congress. Specifically, only **31% of Republicans** are very confident in Trump's ability to work with Congress, indicating a more nuanced perception of his leadership style [7].

In summary, public confidence in Trump's ability to make good appointments to the federal courts is significantly higher among Republicans than Democrats, reflecting a broader trend of partisan confidence in his leadership on key issues like trade and economic policy, but lower confidence in areas such as congressional collaboration.

Confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from presidential decisions varies significantly across political affiliations. Democrats, particularly liberal Democrats, express deep skepticism, with 83% saying they are not at all confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate [2]. In contrast, most Republicans are more confident, with 55% saying they are very confident and an additional 23% somewhat confident that Trump separates his business interests from his decisions [10]. Conservative Republicans are even more confident, with 66% expressing strong confidence [10].

This confidence is notably higher among Republicans compared to the general public. Only 28% of all Americans are very confident that Trump keeps his business interests separate, while 41% are not at all confident [4]. The disparity is further highlighted by the image showing that Republican/Lean Republican respondents are much more likely to express confidence in this area than Democrats/Lean Democrats [image3].

Regarding the perception of Trump's responsibility to release tax returns, there is a notable divide. While 64% of Americans currently believe Trump has this responsibility, a majority of Republicans—64%—still argue he does not [3]. However, this view has shifted over time, as 64% now say he has this responsibility, up slightly from previous years [8]. This suggests a growing consensus among the public, though it remains polarized along party lines.

![{Confidence in Trump separating business interests}](image3)  
![{Perception of Trump’s tax return responsibility}](image4)  

Overall, confidence in Trump's ability to separate his business interests from presidential decisions is considerably higher among Republicans than Democrats, and this aligns with broader perceptions of his responsibility to release tax returns.

The partisan divides significantly affect perceptions of the effectiveness of the U.S. response to the coronavirus and trust in various institutions. As shown in the data, there is a clear divergence in opinions between Republicans and Democrats regarding how effective the U.S. has been compared to other wealthy nations. ![{Republicans and Democrats have divergent views on the U.S. response effectiveness}](image1)  

While 87% of Democrats and Democratic leaners believe the U.S. response has been less effective than other wealthy countries, only 22% of Republicans and Republican leaners share this view, with a larger percentage (34%) believing it has been less effective. This indicates that Democrats are more critical of the national response, while Republicans tend to be more supportive.  

Trust in institutions also reflects these partisan differences. ![{Partisan differences in trust in institutions}](image2) For instance, public health officials such as those at the CDC receive high approval from Democrats (72%) but only 53% from Republicans. Similarly, local and state elected officials are viewed more positively by Democrats than by Republicans.  

The perception of the cause of increased coronavirus cases further highlights these divides. ![{Partisan differences in views on the cause of increased cases}](image3) Democrats are more likely to attribute the rise in cases to growing infections rather than testing increases, whereas Republicans show less agreement with this perspective.  

Trust in public health officials has declined over time, particularly among Republicans. ![{Decline in trust in public health officials over time}](image4) The data shows that confidence in CDC officials dropped from 84% to 53% among Republicans, indicating a significant shift in perception.  

Additionally, the trust in Donald Trump has also seen a decline, especially among Democrats. ![{Trust in Donald Trump and changes in approval ratings}](image5) While Republicans still largely approve of him, Democrats' approval has dropped sharply, reflecting broader partisan tensions.  

In conclusion, partisan divides play a major role in shaping perceptions of the U.S. response to the coronavirus and trust in key institutions.

The perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak by public health officials and Donald Trump has shown significant partisan differences, as reflected in multiple surveys from March to August. ![{Partisan Differences in Approval Ratings for Public Health Officials and Trump}](image3) This image highlights the approval ratings for public health officials such as those at the CDC, where Democrats/Lean Democrats' ratings decreased from 84% to 72%, while Republicans/Lean Republicans' ratings dropped sharply from 74% to 53%. Similarly, the overall total for public health officials fell from 79% to 63%, indicating a notable decline in public confidence, especially among Republicans.

![{Confidence in Public Health Officials and Other Entities}](image5) This chart further illustrates that Democrats/Lean Democrats maintain higher levels of confidence in public health officials (72%) compared to Republicans/Lean Republicans (53%). The disparity underscores how partisan affiliations influence perceptions of the effectiveness and reliability of public health responses.

Regarding Donald Trump, his approval ratings have also declined significantly. ![{Approval Ratings for Donald Trump}](image3) The data shows that the rating for Democrats/Lean Democrats dropped from 18% to 6%, while Republicans/Lean Republicans’ ratings fell from 83% to 73%. This reflects a sharp divergence in how different political groups view Trump's handling of the pandemic.

Moreover, the shift in public opinion is largely driven by Republican sentiments, as noted in the text quotes. [10] The share of Republicans who rate public health officials positively has fallen 31 points, from 84% to 53%, whereas Democrats’ views remain largely unchanged. [2] This pattern is consistent with other findings, such as the decline in positive assessments of state and local officials, which has been steeper among Republicans than Democrats. [8]

In summary, partisan differences significantly impact the perception of the response to the COVID-19 outbreak, with Republicans generally showing lower approval for public health officials and Trump compared to Democrats.

The approval ratings for public health officials and Donald Trump have both declined from March to August, with notable partisan differences in the extent of these changes. Public health officials, such as those at the CDC, saw a significant drop in positive assessments, particularly among Republicans. According to [5], only about half of Republicans (53%) now give CDC officials and other public health officials positive ratings, a 31-point decline from late March (84%). In contrast, Democrats’ views remain largely unchanged, with 72% still rating public health officials positively, similar to their March levels [9]. This shift is reflected in image3, which highlights the stark partisan divide in confidence in public health officials, showing 72% of Democrats and 53% of Republicans holding positive views [image3].

Similarly, Donald Trump’s approval ratings for his handling of the coronavirus have fallen sharply. Currently, 37% of Americans approve of his performance, while 63% disapprove [6]. Among Democrats, the share rating Trump’s response as “poor” has risen steeply, from 56% in March to 82% today [8]. For Republicans, however, Trump’s approval remains relatively high, with 77% currently approving of his job performance [2]. These trends are also captured in image4, which shows the decline in approval ratings for Trump, particularly among Democrats, who dropped from 18% to 6% [image4].

The overall approval ratings for Trump have remained largely stable since June, with 38% of Americans currently approving of his performance as president, compared to 59% disapproving [10]. This is illustrated in image2, which displays the fluctuating approval and disapproval ratings over time, highlighting the broader trend of declining support [image2].

![{The decline in approval ratings for public health officials and Donald Trump, with significant partisan differences}](image4)

The public's perception of state government handling of the coronavirus outbreak is marked by significant concern over the speed at which restrictions were lifted, with 69% of U.S. adults expressing greater worry that states have been too quick to ease public activity restrictions, as shown in ![{concern over lifting restrictions}](image5). This sentiment is further underscored by the fact that while positive evaluations of state officials have declined since March, the public still maintains a largely positive view of local hospital and medical centers, with 88% rating their response as excellent or good, as illustrated in ![{public opinion on hospitals and medical centers}](image1).

In contrast, views of Donald Trump’s response to the pandemic are notably more critical. Nearly half of Americans (48%) rate his performance as “poor,” a significant increase from March, as noted in [4]. Additionally, a majority of Americans, including a substantial portion of Democrats, criticize Trump’s handling of the crisis, with 62% of the total population believing that there are more new infections rather than more tests, as depicted in ![{perceptions of testing and infections}](image4).

Partisan differences are also evident in these assessments. While Democrats are more likely to view the U.S. response as less effective compared to other wealthy nations, Republicans show more varied opinions, with 22% considering the U.S. response more effective, 34% less effective, and 42% about as effective, as highlighted in ![{effectiveness comparison with other nations}](image3). These divergent perspectives reflect broader partisan divides in how the pandemic has been managed and perceived across different levels of government. 

Overall, American perceptions of state government actions during the pandemic differ significantly from views on Trump's handling, with the former focusing more on the pace of restriction lifting and the latter emphasizing criticism of leadership effectiveness and communication.

The public's perception of the effectiveness in handling the coronavirus outbreak reveals a clear divide between elected officials and public health officials. According to the data, while **88%** of Americans rate local hospitals and medical centers as excellent or good in their response [4], the evaluation of elected officials is more mixed. For instance, **62%** of Americans believe the U.S. response has been less effective compared with other wealthy countries, highlighting a general dissatisfaction with the overall approach [4]. 

![{Americans' views on the U.S. response compared to other wealthy countries}](image1)  
This image illustrates that **75%** of Americans consider **"not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing"** as a major reason for the continued outbreak, which aligns with the broader sentiment expressed in the text that public adherence to guidelines is critical [8]. Additionally, **58%** of respondents believe that lifting restrictions too quickly in some places is a major factor contributing to the ongoing spread [8].

The chart further emphasizes that **53%** of Americans view an **"inadequate response from the federal government"** as a major reason for the continued outbreak, indicating significant concerns about federal leadership during the crisis [1]. ![{Trust in government by political affiliation}](image3)  
Trust in government also plays a role in shaping these perceptions. Public health officials, however, maintain relatively high levels of support. **63%** of Americans now rate public health officials as doing an excellent or good job, a decline from **79%** in March, but still showing strong public confidence [2].
