The proportion of favorable views of China among the American public has significantly decreased from 2005 to 2020. In 2005, favorable opinions peaked at around 52%, while by 2020, this figure had dropped to 22%. ![{The proportion of favorable views of China among the American public decreased from 52% in 2005 to 22% in 2020}](image5) This decline reflects a substantial shift in public sentiment over the years.

[1] The percentage of Americans who believe the U.S. is the world’s leading economic power has shown fluctuations over time. ![{The U.S. as the world's leading economic power](image1)] As depicted in image1, the U.S. line, represented in green, starts at 46% in 2008 and fluctuates, increasing to 59% in 2020 before slightly dropping to 52%. This indicates a general upward trend, albeit with some volatility. 

[9] Since March, there has been a decline in the share of Democrats who see the U.S. as the world’s top economy. [7] This shift is further emphasized by the fact that Democrats have become significantly less likely to see the U.S. as the leading global economy, with 54% holding this opinion in March compared to 44% today. 

[2] The decline in confidence in the U.S. as the leading economic power is also reflected in the broader context of the economic impact of the coronavirus pandemic. The International Monetary Fund predicts the U.S. gross domestic product will shrink in 2020, while the Chinese economy will achieve positive growth. This has contributed to a decrease in American economic confidence, with 52% still seeing their country as the world’s leading economic power, down from 59% in March.

[3] Americans’ views on the bilateral economic relationship with China are also associated with their opinion of Xi Jinping. Those who think Sino-U.S. economic relations are bad are significantly more likely to have no confidence in him (61%) than those who think relations are good (44%). 

[4] There is also a notable partisan divide in evaluations of Xi. Republicans and Republican-leaning independents are now 10 points more likely than their Democratic counterparts to have no confidence at all in Xi. This partisan divide has reemerged, contrasting with previous years where partisans were equally likely to lack confidence in the Chinese leader.

[5] When asked about confidence in Chinese President Xi Jinping regarding world affairs, about three-quarters of Americans say they have not too much confidence or no confidence at all (77%). For the first time since 2014, a majority (55%) now say they have no confidence at all in the Chinese president, indicating a significant shift in public perception.

[6] The low confidence in President Xi is tied to concerns over how China has handled the coronavirus pandemic. Americans who believe the Chinese government has done a bad job dealing with the outbreak are significantly more likely to have no confidence in Xi (64%) than those who believe it has done a good job (39%).

[8] The data also highlights the involvement of various researchers and professionals in compiling these insights, ensuring a comprehensive understanding of public sentiment.

In summary, Americans' perceptions of their country's status as the world's leading economic power have generally remained strong but show signs of decline, particularly among Democrats, and are influenced by broader economic and geopolitical factors.

When it comes to identifying the world’s leading economic power, Americans and Germans exhibit notable differences. According to [1], half of Americans name the U.S. as the leading economic power, with about a third (32%) choosing China. In contrast, roughly half of Germans (53%) name China as the leading economic power, while only 24% name the U.S. This divergence highlights a significant shift in perception between the two nations. ![{Germans view China as the leading economic power more than the U.S.}](image3)

The data further illustrates this difference in [6], where the percentages for the U.S. and China are clearly separated, reinforcing the idea that Americans are more likely to see their own country as the top economic power compared to Germans. 

Moreover, relatively few in both countries see Japan or the European Union as the leading economic power, although 14% of Germans name the EU, which is about twice as many as in the U.S. [1] This suggests that while both nations share some views on the global economic landscape, there is a clear distinction in how they perceive the role of major economic players.

![{Comparative approval ratings of international entities by the U.S. and Germany}](image1)  
This bar chart visually represents the differing perceptions of key international entities, including the EU, Russia, China, UN, and NATO, from the perspectives of the U.S. and Germany. It shows that Germany generally has higher approval ratings for these entities compared to the U.S., particularly for the EU, UN, and NATO.

In summary, Americans are more likely to view the U.S. as the leading economic power, whereas Germans are more inclined to see China in that role.

The number of farms in the U.S. decreased significantly from 1880 to 1950, reflecting broader trends of agricultural consolidation and mechanization. In 1880, there were 1,597 farms, but by 1950, this number had dropped to 1,453 [3]. This decline was part of a larger pattern where the average size of farms increased as smaller farms were absorbed by larger operations due to rising costs and technological advancements [1]. The trend of farm consolidation continued throughout the century, with Hamilton County serving as a microcosm of this national shift [1].

![{The number of farms in the U.S. decreased from 1880 to 1950}](image3)

Among various educational and political affiliation groups, perceptions of ethical standards show notable differences. For instance, among those with at least a college degree, $31\%$ say “high ethical standards” does not describe either party, while $43\%$ say it describes one and not the other [1]. Furthermore, $41\%$ of Americans say the GOP has high ethical standards, while a nearly identical share ($42\%$) say this about the Democratic Party [8]. 

![{perceptions of ethical standards by education and political affiliation}](image2)  
Among college graduates, $43\%$ say “high ethical standards” describes one party but not the other, and $41\%$ say it describes neither party [4]. However, fewer of those with some college experience ($26\%$) or a high school degree or less education ($20\%$) think neither party has high ethical standards [10]. 

In terms of political affiliation, independents are significantly more likely than partisans to say neither party has “high ethical standards.” About a third of independents ($34\%$) say neither party has high ethical standards, compared to only about two-in-ten Republicans ($19\%$) or Democrats ($18\%$) [5]. 

![{perceptions of ethical standards by political affiliation}](image4)  
Additionally, partisans are somewhat less positive about their own party in views on whether it has high ethical standards, though majorities of Republicans ($66\%$) and Democrats ($64\%$) describe their party this way [3]. 

Overall, there are differences in attentiveness by race, education, and ideology, with blacks being significantly more likely than either whites or Hispanics to say they have been following campaign news very closely [$30\%$ of blacks compared with $18\%$ of whites and $13\%$ of Hispanics) [7]. 

The public has similar views of the Republican and Democratic parties in assessments of their policy ideas and ethical standards, although somewhat more Americans view the Republican Party than the Democratic Party as “too extreme” [9]. 

![{perceptions of the Republican and Democratic parties}](image3)  
Combining views of both political parties on ethics, a quarter of the public says “high ethical standards” describes neither the Republican Party nor the Democratic Party; $47\%$ say it describes one party but not the other; and $17\%$ say the description applies to both [6]. 

In summary, perceptions of ethical standards differ among various educational and political affiliation groups, with higher education levels and independent affiliations showing more skepticism toward both parties' ethical standards.

The ownership of tablets or e-readers among seniors is notably higher than that of smartphones. According to the data, **18% of seniors own a smartphone**, while **27% own a tablet or e-reader** [5]. This indicates that seniors are more likely to own a tablet or e-reader than a smartphone. 

![{Seniors own more tablets or e-readers than smartphones}(image5)]  

Additionally, the adoption rates for tablets and e-readers among seniors are influenced by factors such as education and income. Seniors who have graduated from college are around three times as likely to own both an e-book reader and a tablet compared to those who have not attended college [2]. Similarly, seniors with an annual household income of $75,000 or more are four times as likely to own each device as those with a household income of less than $30,000 [2].  

While smartphone ownership among seniors has been growing, it remains relatively low, with only **18%** of seniors owning a smartphone, which is well below the national adoption rate of **55%** [6]. Furthermore, smartphone ownership decreases significantly for seniors in their mid-70s and becomes nearly non-existent among those aged 80 and older [7].  

In contrast, tablet ownership among seniors is around half the national average, with **34%** of all U.S. adults owning a tablet, while seniors have a slightly lower rate [4]. However, when considering both tablets and e-readers together, **27% of seniors own at least one of these devices**, which is higher than the **18%** who own a smartphone [5].  

Overall, the ownership of tablets or e-readers among seniors is higher than that of smartphones, reflecting a preference for these devices over smartphones in this demographic.

[5] and [7] indicate that internet use and broadband adoption drop off notably starting at around age 75. For instance, **47%** of seniors aged 75-79 go online, and only **34%** have broadband at home, compared to **74%** who go online and **65%** with broadband at home for those aged 65-69.

The majority of STEM workers in the U.S. are white (69%), followed by Asians (13%), blacks (9%), and Hispanics (7%) [8]. Compared with their shares in the overall workforce, whites and Asians are overrepresented in the STEM workforce, while blacks and Hispanics are underrepresented [8]. Specifically, Asians are overrepresented across all STEM occupational groups, with higher than average shares among computer workers and life scientists, accounting for 19% of workers in both fields, which is much higher than their share in the workforce overall (6%) [7]. ![{Asians are overrepresented in STEM jobs compared to their overall workforce share}](image1)  

Additionally, Asians are overrepresented in the STEM workforce, relative to their overall share of the workforce, especially among college-educated workers: 17% of college-educated STEM workers are Asian, compared with 10% of all workers with a college degree [4]. This trend is also reflected in the data from the bar chart, where Asians make up a larger proportion of STEM workers than their representation in the general workforce [image1].  

On the other hand, Hispanics and blacks are underrepresented in most STEM occupations, as noted in the text quotes [1] and [10]. The bar chart further supports this by showing lower percentages of Hispanics and blacks in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employment categories [image1].  

Whites are also overrepresented in the STEM workforce relative to their share in the total workforce, particularly among those with postgraduate degrees [9]. However, the highest level of overrepresentation is observed among Asians, who are disproportionately represented in STEM fields compared to their overall population share.  

Thus, the racial/ethnic group most represented in STEM jobs compared to their representation in all employment categories is **Asians**.

The approval ratings for public health officials, such as those at the CDC, have seen a notable decline from March to August, with significant differences observed between Democrats and Republicans. According to the data, Democrats' approval ratings remained relatively stable, with 74% in March and 72% in August, showing little change [1]. In contrast, Republicans experienced a substantial drop, with their approval ratings falling from 84% in March to 53% in August, a decrease of 31 points [1]. This shift indicates a marked decline in Republican confidence in public health officials' handling of the coronavirus outbreak.

![{public health officials approval ratings from March to August](image3)]  
The image illustrates the decline in approval ratings for public health officials among different political groups, highlighting the sharp drop among Republicans compared to the more stable trend among Democrats [3].

Additionally, the overall approval rating for public health officials decreased from 79% in March to 63% in August, reflecting a broader trend of reduced public confidence [9]. The decline was predominantly driven by the significant drop in Republican support, while Democratic views remained largely unchanged [2].

The partisan divide is further emphasized by the data showing that Democrats are more likely than Republicans to give positive ratings to state and local government officials for their response to the coronavirus outbreak [10]. This suggests that the perception of governmental effectiveness during the pandemic has been more favorable among Democrats than among Republicans.

In summary, the approval ratings for public health officials declined significantly from March to August, with the most pronounced drop occurring among Republicans.

The financial expectations of Hispanics have consistently been more optimistic than those of the general public from 2004 to 2015. In 2004, about 76% of Hispanics expected their family’s finances to improve, compared to 70% of the general public [9]. By 2008, during the Great Recession, this optimism declined for both groups, with Hispanics at 67% and the general public at 56% [1]. However, Hispanics showed a stronger recovery, increasing to 81% in 2015, while the general public only reached 61% [1][2]. This reflects a significant gap, with Hispanics being 20 percentage points more optimistic than the general public in 2015, the largest gap since the series began [10].

![{Hispanic and General Population Financial Expectations Over Time}](image2)  
The image shows a clear trend of rising optimism among Hispanics, especially after the recession, compared to the general public [2].

From 2004 to 2015, the share of Hispanics who expected their finances to improve “a lot” or “some” increased by 14 percentage points, whereas the general public saw only a 6-point increase [2]. This indicates that Hispanic optimism grew faster than that of the general population during this period.

![{General Population vs. All Hispanics Financial Expectations}](image1)  
The bar chart highlights the consistent rise in financial expectations for Hispanics, surpassing the general public's growth [1].

Additionally, the data reveals that even within the Hispanic community, there was a notable increase in optimism across different age groups. For instance, Hispanics aged 30 to 49 and 50 to 64 saw a 16-point increase in their financial expectations [4]. This suggests a broad-based improvement in economic outlook among Hispanics.

Overall, the financial expectations of Hispanics have remained more positive than those of the general public throughout the period from 2004 to 2015, with a widening gap in optimism over time.

Specifically, 79% of older adults who use the internet agree with the statement that “people without internet access are at a real disadvantage because of all the information they might be missing,” with 47% agreeing strongly. Additionally, 94% of these users agree that the internet makes it much easier to find information today than in the past, with 77% agreeing strongly.

On the other hand, text quote [10] reveals that older adults who do not currently use the internet are divided on the question of whether lacking internet access hurts them. Half of these non-users (49%) agree with the statement that “people lacking internet access are at a real disadvantage because of all the information they might be missing,” with 25% agreeing strongly. However, 35% of these non-users disagree that they are missing out on important information, with 18% strongly disagreeing.

This divergence in views is further illustrated by image3, which compares the levels of agreement between internet users and non-users. For internet users, 47% strongly agree that people without internet access are at a disadvantage, while 31% somewhat agree, totaling 79%. In contrast, for non-users, 25% strongly agree, and 24% somewhat agree, resulting in a total of 48%.

![{Diverging views on internet access disadvantages}](image3)

There is a notable perception among Americans that China's influence in world affairs may diminish following the coronavirus outbreak. According to the survey, half of Americans believe China will have less influence after the pandemic, with significant partisan and age-related divides [1]. ![{half believe China's influence will decline}](image4)  

Republicans are more likely than Democrats to think China’s international clout will diminish, with roughly six-in-ten Republicans holding this view compared to just 40% of Democrats [1]. Additionally, older Americans are more inclined to believe in this decline, showing a 16 percentage point difference compared to those under 30 [1].  

The survey also reveals that many Americans see long-term impacts on China’s global stature, with 50% expressing the belief that its influence will decrease post-pandemic [3]. This sentiment aligns with a broader trend of rising unfavorable opinions toward China, reaching a peak of 66% of Americans holding an unfavorable view of the country [3].  

While there are differences in how various groups perceive China’s influence, the overall consensus is that a substantial portion of the American public believes China’s global standing will be affected negatively by the pandemic. ![{perceptions of U.S. influence post-pandemic}](image5)  

In summary, Americans largely perceive China's influence in world affairs as likely to decline after the pandemic.

Public satisfaction with the state of the nation has shown a consistent decline over time from 1990 to 2019, as illustrated by ![{public dissatisfaction trend}](image4). In 1990, about 41% of Americans were satisfied with the way things were going in the country, while 54% were dissatisfied. By 2019, this trend had shifted significantly, with only 26% expressing satisfaction and 70% indicating dissatisfaction. This represents a steady decrease in satisfaction levels over the past three decades.

The data also reveals that dissatisfaction has become more pronounced in recent years. For instance, in September 2019, 61% of adults reported being dissatisfied, and by the time of the survey, this figure had increased by 9 percentage points, reaching its highest level in the past year [4]. Furthermore, the gap between satisfaction and dissatisfaction has widened, with the lowest level of GOP satisfaction recorded since late 2017, where 47% of Republicans were dissatisfied, matching the number of those who were satisfied [8].

These trends reflect broader shifts in public sentiment, including growing polarization and economic concerns. While some segments of the population, such as Republicans, have seen changes in their views on economic policies, overall satisfaction remains low, indicating a deepening sense of discontent across the country.

The trend depicted in the assembly of Net Asset Value (NAV) for European venture funds by vintage year shows a significant shift in the realization of investments over time. From 1997 to 2004, the NAV chart illustrates a mix of realized and unrealized portions, with the realized portion generally decreasing while the unrealized portion remained substantial, especially from 2001 to 2004. This indicates a period of uncertainty and underperformance during the post-bubble phase. ![{The assembly of Net Asset Value (NAV) for European venture funds by vintage year from 1997 to 2009, showing a transition from mixed realized and unrealized portions to predominantly unrealized investments post-2005}](image4)  

Starting from 2005 to 2009, all bars are labeled as 100% unrealized, highlighting the "Post-bubble vintages" and suggesting that these funds have not yet been fully realized. This reflects a phase of unrealized investments following the financial bubble, indicating a long tail of non-contributing funds in the Thomson database [4]. The trend underscores a shift towards a more mature and resilient venture capital ecosystem in Europe, where post-bubble vintages are now at an inflection point, demonstrating improved performance and stronger exit outcomes [1].

The expectations of Trump and Clinton voters regarding the impact of Trump's election on race relations reveal significant differences. According to the data, among Trump voters, half (50%) expect race relations to get better, while 38% think his election will make no difference, and only 9% believe it will get worse [1]. In contrast, a majority of Clinton voters—84%—expect race relations to worsen under Trump, with just 13% thinking there will be no change and 2% expecting improvement [8]. This stark divide highlights how the election outcome was perceived differently by supporters of each candidate.

![{Clinton and Trump Voters' Expectations on Race Relations}(image2)]  
This image further illustrates the contrasting views, showing that while 50% of Trump voters expect improvement in race relations, 84% of Clinton voters anticipate deterioration [8].

Additionally, the overall sentiment among voters shows that 46% of all voters believe Trump’s election will lead to worse race relations, compared to 25% who expect improvement, and 26% who think there will be no change [10]. However, this general sentiment is heavily influenced by the strong pessimism expressed by Clinton voters, who are more likely than previous groups to view Trump's presidency negatively in terms of race relations [5].

In summary, Trump voters are significantly more optimistic about the impact of Trump's election on race relations compared to Clinton voters, who express widespread concern about its negative effects.

The median multiple of cash invested in Europe is 7.2, while in the USA it is 4.5, indicating that European investments generally achieve higher returns relative to the amount invested [3]. This suggests a more efficient use of capital in Europe, which aligns with the observation that European VC-backed IPO performance matches or exceeds US performance, both pre- and post-IPO [7]. 

![{Europe has a higher median multiple of cash invested compared to the USA}](image3)  

Despite the lower median exit valuation in Europe ($173 million versus $236 million in the USA), the combination of lower entry valuations and higher capital efficiency compensates for this difference, leading to better overall performance [9]. The structure and performance of European venture capital illustrate its unparalleled potential as a matured industry [3]. 

In addition, the scarcity of VC money in Europe has driven up capital efficiency, roughly 70 percent higher than in the US, further contributing to the strong performance of European funds [4]. However, visibility on European VC funds for investors remains limited due to poor quality of published industry fund statistics [8]. 

The comparison of investment performances between Europe and the USA highlights the distinct advantages of European venture capital, particularly in terms of return multiples [3].

The question asks which age group believes the least that China's global influence will increase after the coronavirus outbreak. According to the data, there is a clear pattern in how different age groups perceive China's influence post-pandemic.

Thus, the age group that believes the least that China's global influence will increase after the coronavirus outbreak is those aged 65 and older.

[3] Both Republicans and Democrats have become more likely to say that the government’s anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough to protect the country (rather than that they have gone too far restricting civil liberties) since Snowden’s disclosures in 2013. But the shift has been more pronounced among Republicans. Slightly more than seven-in-ten Republicans $(71\%)$ now say their greater concern is that anti-terrorism policies do not go far enough, up 14 points since January $(57\%)$ and 33 points since July 2013 $(38\%)$ .  

![{Republicans' views on anti-terrorism policies have shifted significantly over time}](image2)  

[4] Compared to early 2015, assessments of government efforts to combat terrorism are more negative across the political spectrum. Democrats are now the only partisan group in which a majority $(64\%)$ say the government is doing at least fairly well (down from $85\%$ in January). Independents’ positive ratings have dropped 25 points, from $69\%$ to $44\%$. And just $27\%$ of Republicans now say the government is doing very or fairly well reducing the terrorist threat, down from $63\%$ at the beginning of the year.  

[6] Americans’ ratings of the government’s efforts to reduce the threat of terrorism are now lower than at any point since the September 2001 terrorist attacks. For the first time, more now say the government is doing not too well or not at all well in reducing the threat of terrorism $(52\%)$ than say the government is doing either very or fairly well $(46\%)$. Positive ratings have fallen 26 points since January (when $72\%$ said very/fairly well).  

![{Republicans' approval of government efforts against terrorism has declined significantly}](image3)  

[2] The views of conservative Republicans, in particular, have turned sharply critical: In January, $59\%$ said the government was doing very well or fairly well; today, only $18\%$ say this.  

[7] Over the course of his first term, the public generally gave Obama positive marks for his handling of the threat of terrorism, peaking at $69\%$ approval in May 2011 following the killing of Osama bin Laden. But his ratings were divided earlier this year $(46\%$ approval in May) and now are in negative territory.  

[8] PEW RESEARCH CENTER Views of Obama’s handling of the threat of terrorism have always been strongly associated with partisanship. And his ratings have dropped across all partisan groups.  

![{Republicans' views on government efforts to combat terrorism have become increasingly negative over time}](image4)  

Republicans' views on government efforts to reduce the terrorist threat have shifted significantly over time, with increasing concerns about insufficient anti-terrorism measures and declining approval of government performance.

The Pew Research Center survey highlights significant gender disparities in STEM fields, particularly in computer-related jobs. Specifically, 74% of women in computer jobs say they have experienced discrimination, compared to 50% of all women in STEM jobs. Furthermore, the survey indicates that women in computer jobs are more likely to feel treated as if they are not competent at work due to their gender, with 40% reporting this experience, compared to 29% of all women in STEM jobs. Among people in STEM jobs, the type of STEM major with the largest gender gap in consistent employment and pay is **computer jobs**.

The perception that news organizations had 'too much' influence on presidential elections has shown a consistent upward trend over time, as evidenced by the data from various surveys. For instance, in 1992, 46% of voters believed the press had too much influence, which increased to 53% in 2000 and further rose to 57% in 2016. This indicates a significant shift in public opinion regarding the role of the media in shaping election outcomes. ![{perception of media influence over time}](image1)  

Additionally, the percentage of voters who felt the press had about the right amount of influence decreased over the years, with 49% in 1992 dropping to just 27% in 2016. Conversely, the share of voters who thought the press had too little influence remained relatively low, hovering around 2-7% during this period. ![{perception of media influence over time}](image1)  

This trend is also reflected in specific election contexts. For example, after George W. Bush’s reelection, only 45% of his voters believed the press had too much influence, whereas six-in-ten Trump voters (62%) held this view following the 2016 election. Similarly, 50% of Clinton voters also expressed that the press had too much influence. These figures highlight a growing skepticism or concern among voters, particularly those supporting different candidates, regarding the media's role in influencing election results.  

Moreover, the overall sentiment toward the press has become more negative, with 57% of voters in 2016 stating that the press had too much influence, the highest percentage since 2000. This reflects a broader societal shift in how the media is perceived in the political landscape. ![{perception of media influence over time}](image1)  

In summary, the perception that news organizations had 'too much' influence on presidential elections has increased significantly over time, with the highest recorded level in 2016.

The perception of Trump's economic policies changed significantly from October 2017 to January 2019, with notable differences between Republicans and Democrats. Among Republicans, there was a marked increase in positive views, as indicated by the data showing that 79% of Republicans and Republican leaners believed Trump’s economic policies had improved conditions, up from 63% in October 2017 [8]. This surge in optimism is further supported by the fact that 75% of Republicans rated the economy as excellent or good in January 2019, compared to just 14% in December 2016 [4]. 

![{Republicans' positive economic views increased}](image4)  
Among Democrats, however, the perception remained largely negative. In January 2019, only 10% of Democrats and Democratic leaners thought Trump’s policies had made conditions better, while 46% believed they had made things worse [8]. This reflects a growing polarization in views of Trump’s economic policies, with Democrats becoming more critical over time.

![{Democrats' negative views of Trump's economic policies}](image3)  

Overall, the shift in perception highlights a stark divide between the two parties, with Republicans showing increasing optimism and Democrats expressing continued skepticism about the impact of Trump’s economic policies.

The question of how perceptions of U.S. involvement in solving global problems differ among political affiliations is illuminated by both textual data and visual representations. According to [1], there are wide partisan divides on the most important problem facing the nation, with Republicans more likely than Democrats to view national security and terrorism as major threats. This aligns with the findings in image1, which shows a consistent pattern of higher concern among Republicans compared to Democrats and Independents regarding Islamic extremism, both globally and within the U.S.

![{Republicans show higher concern about Islamic extremism globally and domestically compared to Democrats and Independents}](image1)

Further, [8] indicates that comparable majorities of both Republicans (62%) and Democrats (56%) say world problems would be worse without U.S. involvement. However, [10] highlights that 55% of respondents believe problems in the world would be even worse without U.S. involvement, while only 38% think U.S. efforts usually make things worse. This suggests a general consensus across political lines that U.S. involvement is seen as beneficial, though with some nuances.

Image5 provides a direct comparison of perceptions among political affiliations regarding U.S. involvement in global issues. It reveals that Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe that U.S. efforts usually make things worse, with 37% of Democrats holding this view compared to 31% of Republicans. Conversely, Republicans are more likely to believe that problems would be worse without U.S. involvement, with 62% of Republicans holding this belief versus 56% of Democrats.

![{Democrats are more likely than Republicans to believe U.S. efforts usually make things worse, while Republicans are more likely to believe problems would be worse without U.S. involvement}](image5)

In addition, [9] notes that Republicans more commonly mention immigration as the most important problem, while Democrats are more likely to cite partisan gridlock and division. This reflects broader ideological differences that influence views on U.S. involvement in global matters.

Overall, perceptions of U.S. involvement in solving global problems are shaped by political affiliation, with Republicans generally expressing greater concern about threats like terrorism and a stronger belief in the necessity of U.S. involvement, while Democrats are more skeptical of the effectiveness of such involvement and more concerned about its potential negative consequences.

Among self-identified Hispanics, generational differences significantly affect the likelihood of having Hispanic friends. ![{Generational Differences in Having Hispanic Friends}](image1)  
As shown in the bar chart, foreign-born Hispanics are most likely to have Hispanic friends, with 77% reporting that all or most of their friends are Hispanic. This percentage drops to 55% among second-generation Hispanics and further declines to 37% among third or higher generation Hispanics. The data highlights a clear trend where closer ties to immigrant roots correlate with stronger connections to Hispanic communities.  

![{Perceptions of Shared Heritage Among Generations}](image2)  
The image also illustrates how perceptions of shared heritage vary across generations. While 41% of foreign-born Hispanics believe that all or most of their neighbors share their heritage, this figure drops to 30% for third or higher generation Hispanics. This suggests that as generations progress, the sense of community and shared cultural identity may weaken.  

Additionally, ![{Connection to Hispanic Heritage by Generation}](image4) reveals that connection to Hispanic heritage diminishes with each generation. Foreign-born Hispanics show the highest level of connection at 82%, while only 44% of third or higher generation Hispanics feel very or somewhat connected to their family’s country of origin. This decline in cultural connection may contribute to the reduced likelihood of maintaining strong ties to Hispanic friends.  

In conclusion, generational differences among self-identified Hispanics result in a decreasing likelihood of having Hispanic friends as the distance from immigrant roots increases.

The difference in gender-related discrimination experiences between men and women in computer jobs is significant, as evidenced by multiple sources. Women in these roles are far more likely to report experiencing discrimination compared to their male counterparts. For instance, **74% of women in computer jobs** say they have experienced gender-related workplace discrimination, whereas only **16% of men** in these jobs share the same experience [5]. This stark contrast highlights a substantial disparity in how men and women perceive and experience discrimination in the tech industry.

![{Women in computer jobs are more likely to experience gender-related discrimination than men}(image2)]  
This image further illustrates the gap, showing that women in computer jobs are not only more likely to experience discrimination but also face challenges such as sexual harassment, difficulty succeeding due to gender, and unfair treatment in recruitment and hiring processes. The data underscores that women in these roles often encounter systemic barriers that men do not.

Additionally, women in computer jobs are less likely than men to believe that women are "usually" given a fair shake in terms of promotion and advancement opportunities. Only **43% of women** in computer jobs hold this view, compared to **77% of men** [7]. This perception of unfairness reinforces the notion that gender-related discrimination is deeply embedded in the workplace culture for women in these fields.

In conclusion, women in computer jobs experience significantly higher rates of gender-related discrimination compared to men in the same roles.

Despite the challenges older adults face with technology, many still engage regularly with the digital world. However, physical health conditions significantly impact their ability to use technology compared to all adults. For instance, **23% of older adults** report having a "physical or health condition that makes reading difficult or challenging," which is higher than the **16%** reported by all adults [image1]. Similarly, **29% of older adults** have a "disability, handicap, or chronic disease that prevents them from fully participating in many common daily activities," compared to **18%** of all adults [image1].

These physical challenges result in lower adoption rates of digital tools among older adults. For example, only **13%** of physically challenged seniors own a smartphone, compared to **22%** of those without such challenges [3]. Additionally, they are significantly less likely to go online, with just **49%** using the internet regularly, versus **66%** of seniors without these challenges [9].

The disparity is further reflected in ownership of major digital devices. Seniors with physical challenges are less likely to own cell phones (**69%** vs. **82%**) and smartphones (**13%** vs. **22%**) [3]. While differences in technology adoption between these groups are somewhat more modest for tablets and e-book readers, **22%** of physically challenged seniors own either a tablet or an e-book reader, compared to a higher percentage among other seniors [10].

Overall, physical health conditions create substantial barriers to technology use among older adults, making them more disconnected from digital life compared to all adults. This highlights the need for tailored solutions to support seniors with physical challenges in accessing and utilizing technology effectively.

The importance of abortion as an issue among Latino registered voters increased significantly from March to August. In March, 42% of Latino voters considered abortion very important, but by August, this percentage had risen to 57%. This increase is particularly notable among Hispanic Democrats and Democratic leaners, who saw a rise from 42% in March to 63% in August. ![Abortion Importance Increase](image2)  

This shift in perception aligns with the broader context of the 2022 midterm elections, where abortion became a more prominent issue for Latino voters, especially in light of the Supreme Court's decision to end the federal guarantee of a right to legal abortion in the United States. ![Abortion as Election Issue](image4)  

Among all issues, the economy remained the top concern for Latino voters, with 80% considering it very important, while abortion and immigration also ranked highly, with 57% and 54% respectively. ![Top Issues for Latino Voters](image5)  

The growing significance of abortion as a voting issue reflects changing priorities and political dynamics within the Latino community leading up to the 2022 congressional elections. The importance of abortion as a voting issue increased from 42% in March to 57% in August among Latino registered voters.

The catalog share of streams for Rock is 82% while for Pop it is 58%, as indicated by the data in image1 [![{catalog share of streams comparison](image1)]. In contrast, only **45%** of Latinos say the same about the Republican Party. This indicates a stronger perception among Latinos that the Democratic Party works harder to earn their votes.

In the image, the pie chart illustrates the composition of a gas mixture, showing Carbon Dioxide (CO₂) as 13.7% [10]. Additionally, the bar chart indicates that Nitrous Oxide (NOx) constitutes 0.1% of the pollutants in the exhaust [1]. The greenhouse effect is an essential process where infrared rays from the sun are trapped by the atmosphere, keeping the Earth warm [9]. However, greenhouse gases like CO₂ and NOx are disrupting this natural balance, leading to global warming [4].  

Thus, the first two gases that cause the greenhouse effect, along with their proportions in the exhaust gas from a gasoline-engine, are **Carbon Dioxide (CO₂) at 13.7%** and **Nitrogen Oxides (NOx) at 0.1%**.

The approval ratings of the redistricting proposal show a clear divide between Republicans and Democrats. According to the data, **49% of adults approve** of the proposal to require states to form redistricting commissions with equal numbers of Democrats and Republicans, while **13% disapprove**, and **38% are unsure** [2]. This indicates a majority support for the proposal overall. However, when looking at partisan differences, **Democrats are more likely than Republicans to favor replacing state legislatures with independent commissions** for drawing congressional maps [1].

![{approval ratings by party}](image4)  
Among specific groups, **Republicans and Republican leaners** are somewhat more likely to disapprove of these non-legislative commissions compared to Democrats. Specifically, **19% of Republicans and Republican leaners disapprove**, whereas only **8% of Democrats and Democratic leaners disapprove** [10]. Additionally, a larger share of Republicans and Republican leaners are unsure about the proposal (42%) compared to Democrats (32%) [10].

In contrast, **Democrats and Democratic leaners** show stronger approval, with **59% approving** the proposal, compared to **38% of Republicans and Republican leaners** [4]. This suggests that while the proposal has broad support across the general population, it is more favored by Democrats than by Republicans.

The approval ratings of the redistricting proposal vary significantly between Republicans and Democrats, with Democrats showing stronger support than Republicans.

The most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak, according to the Pew Research Center survey, is that **not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines**. This reason is highlighted as the top concern among Americans, with **75%** identifying it as a major factor in the ongoing spread of the virus.  

![{not enough people social distancing and mask-wearing}(image1)]  
This is supported by the data from the bar chart in image1, which shows that **75%** of respondents consider this a major reason for the continued outbreak. Additionally, image4 further reinforces this point by displaying that **89%** of Democrats and **57%** of Republicans also cite this as a significant issue, contributing to the overall consensus.  

![{partisan differences on social distancing}(image4)]  

While other factors such as an inadequate federal government response (53%) and restrictions being lifted too quickly (58%) are also frequently mentioned, they do not surpass the level of agreement seen for insufficient adherence to public health guidelines.  

![{major reasons for spread}(image1)]  

The most cited major reason for the continuation of the COVID-19 outbreak is that **not enough people are following social distancing and mask-wearing guidelines**.

Cyber attacks from China showed the greatest increase in concern among Americans from 2020 to 2021, with the percentage of people considering them a very serious problem rising by 7 percentage points, from 58% in 2020 to 65% in 2021. ![{Cyber attacks from China increased concern from 2020 to 2021}](image4)  

Similarly, concerns about China’s policies on human rights also saw a significant rise, increasing by 7 percentage points from 43% in 2020 to 50% in 2021. ![{Concerns about China's human rights policies rose from 2020 to 2021}](image4)  

The loss of U.S. jobs to China, China’s growing military power, and China’s growing technological power each saw increases of 6 percentage points during the same period. ![{Concerns about China's military and technological power rose from 2020 to 2021}](image4)  

These trends reflect a growing perception of China as a significant challenge to U.S. interests across various domains. The most notable increase in concern was observed for cyber attacks from China.

Women's representation in STEM jobs varies significantly by education level compared to the overall employed population. According to the data, among those with a high school or less education, 55% are in STEM jobs, which is higher than the 41% of all employed individuals with similar education levels [3]. For those with some college education, 59% are in STEM jobs, compared to 50% of all employed individuals [3]. Among individuals with a bachelor's degree, 47% are in STEM jobs, slightly lower than the 49% of all employed individuals with this level of education [3]. The percentage of women with a master's degree in STEM jobs is 47%, compared to 54% of all employed individuals with a master's degree [3]. Finally, for those with professional or doctoral degrees, 41% are in STEM jobs, which is close to the 42% of all employed individuals with such degrees [3].

![{Women's representation in STEM jobs by education level compared to the overall employed population}](image3)  

This variation highlights that while women with higher education levels are increasingly represented in STEM jobs, there remains a gap when compared to their presence in the broader workforce. The data also suggest that the trend of increasing women's participation in STEM jobs has been most pronounced among those with advanced degrees [5].

The representation of women in STEM jobs varies significantly across different job clusters, as highlighted by multiple sources. For instance, **health-related jobs** show the highest female participation, with women comprising about 75% of healthcare practitioners and technicians [3]. In contrast, **engineering occupations** have the lowest share of women, at around 14%, while **computer occupations** also exhibit relatively low representation, with women making up approximately 25% of the workforce [8]. 

![{Women's Representation in STEM Job Clusters}](image3)  
This image provides a clear visual comparison of the share of women across various STEM job clusters, illustrating that while health-related fields are predominantly female, other areas like engineering and computer jobs remain heavily male-dominated.

In addition to these disparities, the overall share of women in STEM jobs is driven largely by their overrepresentation in health-related roles, which accounts for the largest portion of the STEM workforce [3]. However, there has been a decline in the proportion of women in certain STEM clusters, such as computer occupations, where their representation has decreased from 32% in 1990 to 25% today [6].

Furthermore, women’s representation in STEM jobs tends to be lower among those with advanced degrees, particularly in engineering and computer fields, where only about 41% of workers holding professional or doctoral degrees are women [5]. This trend underscores the challenges women face in advancing within certain STEM disciplines despite their educational achievements.

Overall, female representation in STEM is not uniform across all job clusters, with notable variations in both opportunity and success.

Among the demographic groups, Latinos showed the largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015. The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve “a lot” or “some” in the coming year rose by 14 percentage points, from 67% in 2008 to 81% in 2015. ![{The share of Latinos who expect their family finances to improve has increased significantly from 2008 to 2015}](image1)  

Furthermore, the gap in financial expectations between Latinos and the general public widened, with Latinos reaching 81% optimism compared to 61% for the general public. This represents a 20 percentage point difference, which is the largest since the series began. ![{The gap in financial optimism between Latinos and the general public has grown}](image2)  

Additionally, within the Latino population, certain subgroups, such as those with some college education, experienced even greater increases in optimism. For instance, Latinos with some college education saw a 20 percentage point rise in financial optimism, outpacing other educational groups. ![{Subgroups within the Latino population show varying levels of financial optimism}](image3)  

The overall trend indicates that while most major demographic groups recorded increases in economic optimism, the most significant gains were observed among Latinos. ![{Financial optimism among Latinos has increased more rapidly than other groups}](image4)  

The largest increase in financial optimism from 2008 to 2015 was shown by Latinos.

The unfavorable opinion of China has shown a significant upward trend across different age groups from 2005 to 2020, as illustrated by the data. ![{Unfavorable views across age groups](image2)]  

For instance, the "18-29" group (blue line) started at 26% in 2005 and increased to 56% in 2020, reflecting a growing negative perception among younger Americans. The "30-49" group (gray line) began at 41% in 2005 and reached 67% in 2020, showing a steady rise in unfavorable opinions. The "50 and older" group (green line) started at 34% in 2005 and surged to 81% in 2020, indicating a particularly sharp increase in negativity among older Americans [2].  

This trend aligns with broader findings that older Americans are more likely to view China negatively compared to younger generations. For example, while only about a quarter of those aged 18 to 29 see China as a partner, just 6% of those 50 and older share this view [2]. Conversely, older Americans are nearly three times as likely as their younger counterparts to see China as an enemy [2].  

Moreover, the overall unfavorable view of China has reached historic highs, with 73% of U.S. adults holding an unfavorable opinion today, up 26 percentage points since 2018 [4]. This shift is also reflected in the partisan divide, where Republicans and Republican-leaning independents hold more unfavorable views than Democrats [8].  

In summary, the unfavorable opinion of China has increased significantly across all age groups from 2005 to 2020, with older Americans showing the most pronounced rise in negative sentiment.

[1] The population of Hamilton County experienced significant growth from 1870 to 1890, increasing from 130 to 14,096. This surge was followed by a gradual decline, as noted in [3]. ![Population Growth and Decline](image3)  
[2] By the early 1920s, the number of school districts had grown to over 100, reflecting the expanding population and educational needs during this period. However, by the late 20th century, consolidation had reduced the number of districts significantly, with only a handful remaining today.  
[3] Table 2 provides a detailed account of the population trends across different towns, showing that some communities saw peaks between 1900 and 1940, while others, like Aurora, continued to grow steadily. ![Population Trends in Towns](image2)  
[4] Despite these gains, the overall trend for many rural communities has been one of decline, particularly as farm consolidation continues to impact local economies. Pat Dinslage (1992) highlights the dependency of small towns on surrounding farming communities, which often leads to population losses.  
[5] The agricultural landscape of Hamilton County has also undergone substantial changes, with mechanization leading to larger farms and fewer individual units. This shift has had significant implications for rural life and community structures. ![Agricultural Changes](image6)  
[6] The introduction of center-pivot irrigation systems in the early 1970s further transformed the county’s land use, converting much of the rangeland into cropland. This development contributed to the expansion of agricultural activities and the associated economic shifts.  
[7] The historical settlement patterns, beginning with Jarvil Chaffee's homestead in 1866, laid the foundation for the county’s growth. However, the movement of populations and the establishment of rail connections played a crucial role in shaping the distribution of communities. ![Historical Settlement](image4)  
[8] Overall, the population of Hamilton County increased from 130 in 1870 to 9,403 in 2000, though the trajectory was not linear, with periods of both growth and decline influenced by agricultural, economic, and transportation factors.

The experiences of discrimination and perceptions of fairness in STEM jobs reveal significant disparities between racial and ethnic groups, particularly between Black and White workers. According to the data, **62% of Black STEM workers** have experienced workplace discrimination because of their race or ethnicity, compared to just **13% of White STEM workers** [4]. This stark difference underscores the heightened challenges faced by Black professionals in these fields.

Furthermore, **43% of Black STEM workers** believe that Black employees are usually treated fairly during recruitment, while only **78% of White STEM workers** share this belief [3]. Similarly, when it comes to promotion and advancement opportunities, **37% of Black STEM workers** feel these processes are fair, versus **75% of White workers** [3]. These figures highlight a perception among Black workers that they are not receiving equitable treatment in key career development areas.

![{Black workers perceive less fairness in hiring and promotions}](image4)  
This image reinforces the findings from the text, showing that Black workers are more likely to report discrimination and less likely to believe in fair treatment during hiring and promotions.

In contrast, **White STEM workers** are more confident in the fairness of workplace processes, with **78%** believing that Black employees are treated fairly during hiring and **75%** feeling the same about promotion opportunities [3]. This confidence is notably absent among Black workers, who are more skeptical about the fairness of these systems.

Additionally, **40% of Black STEM workers** say their race or ethnicity has made it harder to find success in their job, compared to just **5% of White STEM workers** [2]. This disparity suggests that systemic barriers persist for Black professionals in STEM, affecting both their career progression and overall job satisfaction.

Overall, the experiences of discrimination and perceptions of fairness differ significantly between Black and White workers in STEM jobs, with Black workers facing greater challenges and lower confidence in the fairness of workplace practices.

The impact of pre-training on BLEU scores varies across different language pairs, as demonstrated by the data. For higher-resource languages like **PT → EN**, the gains from pre-training are relatively small, with a slight decrease in scores when embeddings are aligned, as shown in image1 where the unaligned score is 30.8 and the aligned score is 30.6 [image1]. In contrast, for extremely low-resource languages such as **GL → EN**, pre-training leads to significant improvements, with an increase of up to 11 BLEU points, highlighting its effectiveness in boosting performance for less-resourced languages [1].

Pre-training also plays a crucial role in enhancing the quality of translations for rare vocabulary and multi-word phrases, as seen in the qualitative analysis of **GL → EN** translations, where the model successfully translated names and complex terms like “big lawyer” and “patent legislation” [2]. This improvement is further supported by image8, which illustrates that pre-training enhances accuracy, especially for low-frequency words in the training corpus [image8].

Moreover, the relationship between training set size and BLEU scores reveals that pre-training provides more substantial gains when the training data is limited. As depicted in image2, the gain from pre-training is most pronounced at smaller training set sizes, suggesting that pre-training can be particularly beneficial for low-resource scenarios [image2].

In multilingual settings, aligning word embeddings across similar languages, such as **GL / PT**, improves BLEU scores significantly, as seen in image10, where aligned embeddings lead to better performance compared to unaligned ones [image10]. However, for less similar language pairs like **BE / RU**, the benefits of alignment are less pronounced, indicating that the effectiveness of pre-training depends on the linguistic similarity between languages [5].

Overall, pre-training consistently improves BLEU scores, especially for low-resource languages, by providing better representations of rare concepts and enabling models to generate more grammatically correct translations. The extent of improvement varies depending on the baseline performance and the degree of similarity between source and target languages. 

![{pre-training improves BLEU scores for low-resource languages}](image1)  
![{pre-training benefits more at smaller training set sizes}](image2)  
![{pre-training enhances accuracy for low-frequency words}](image8)  
![{alignment of embeddings boosts BLEU scores for similar languages}](image10)  

Pre-training generally increases BLEU scores, with larger gains observed for low-resource languages and when the baseline system is moderately effective.

The inclusion of reference translations significantly enhances the performance of the COMET-RANK metric for language pairs involving English, as evidenced by the improvement in scores when references are included. This is reflected in the Δτ values, which indicate the increase in correlation with human judgments when references are used. For instance, in the reverse direction (source to English), the improvements are more pronounced, such as a Δτ of 0.155 for de-en and 0.132 for tr-en, suggesting that references play a crucial role in capturing semantic similarity and improving the metric's alignment with human evaluations.

![{The inclusion of reference translations improves COMET-RANK performance across English-target language pairs}](image2)

In comparison across different language pairs, the impact of including references varies. For example, in en-cs, the Δτ is 0.051, while in cs-en, it is 0.107, indicating that the benefit of using references is more substantial when English is the target language. Similarly, for de-en, the Δτ is 0.155, highlighting a notable improvement when references are incorporated. These variations suggest that the effectiveness of references in enhancing COMET-RANK depends on the specific language pair and the direction of translation, with greater gains observed when English is the target language.

To calculate the difference between the highest and lowest AUPRC values for the **BoolQ dataset**, we need to examine the relevant metrics from the provided text and image quotes. 

From the **text quotes**, [1] and [3] mention the use of **AUPRC (Area Under the Precision-Recall Curve)** as a metric for evaluating token scores in soft scoring models, particularly for datasets like BoolQ. Additionally, [5] refers to **BoolQ** as one of the datasets with very long inputs that required special handling, such as using GloVe embeddings instead of BERT.

In the **image quotes**, **image2** provides performance evaluation metrics for different NLP approaches across several datasets, including **BoolQ**. It reports three metrics: **Perf. (Performance)**, **IOU F1**, and **Token F1**. However, it does not explicitly list **AUPRC** values for the **BoolQ** dataset. 

On the other hand, **image5** presents performance metrics for various model variants across multiple datasets, including **BoolQ**, and includes **AUPRC** as one of the reported metrics. The table lists the following models and explanation methods: **Attention, Gradient, Lime, and Random**, along with their respective **AUPRC** values for each dataset. This is the most direct source for the **AUPRC** values for the **BoolQ** dataset.

From **image5**, the **AUPRC** values for the **BoolQ** dataset are:
- **Attention**: 0.74
- **Gradient**: 0.69
- **Lime**: 0.66
- **Random**: 0.58

The highest **AUPRC** value is **0.74** (from the **Attention** method), and the lowest is **0.58** (from the **Random** method). Therefore, the **difference** between the highest and lowest **AUPRC** values is:

$$
0.74 - 0.58 = 0.16
$$

The **model combinations** corresponding to these values are:
- **Highest AUPRC (0.74)**: **Attention** method.
- **Lowest AUPRC (0.58)**: **Random** method.

![{AUPRC comparison for BoolQ dataset}(image5)]

As the number of demonstration samples increases, the Micro-F1 performance on both MAVEN-ER and Causal-TimeBank (CTB) datasets shows a general trend of improvement, but with diminishing returns beyond a certain point. This is evident from the data presented in the table, where increasing the number of demonstrations from 1 to 5 leads to significant gains in performance, while further increases (e.g., ≥10) yield limited improvements [10]. 

![{The Micro-F1 scores for MAVEN-ERE and CTB datasets increase with the number of demonstration samples, showing diminishing returns after a certain threshold}](image4)

When logical constraints are incorporated into the model instructions, the performance improvements become more consistent and stable, even with fewer demonstrations. For instance, using logical constraints alongside a smaller number of demonstrations (e.g., 5) can surpass the performance achieved by using a larger number of demonstrations without logical constraints (e.g., 10) [10].

![{Incorporating logical constraints with a smaller number of demonstrations significantly improves Micro-F1 scores compared to using more demonstrations without constraints}](image4)

Without logical constraints, the performance gains plateau as the number of demonstrations increases, indicating that additional examples alone may not be sufficient to enhance model performance effectively. In contrast, when logical constraints are applied, the model benefits more consistently from the increased number of demonstrations, leading to better overall results [10].

The inclusion of logical constraints also helps reduce logical inconsistency, as seen in the decrease in LI percentages across various configurations. However, this comes at the cost of potentially introducing more redundant or unnecessary information during inference, which could affect the quality of the final output [6].

In summary, the number of demonstration samples positively affects Micro-F1 performance, especially when combined with logical constraints, which provide a more structured and effective way to guide the model's reasoning process.

The main error types identified in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are primarily attributed to the **Reasoning step**, which is the dominant source of errors. According to the text, more than 90% of the errors occur during the Reasoning step, with **Reasoning Error** and **Math Error** being the major contributors [9]. Additionally, there are other error categories such as **Principle Error**, which relates to failures in the Abstraction step, and **Scoring Error**, which involves mistakes made by the judge model during evaluation [2].

![{Reasoning and Math Errors dominate in TimeQA}](image3)  
The image illustrates that among the four error types during the Reasoning step, **Reasoning Error** and **Math Error** have higher values compared to others, indicating their significant impact on performance [image3]. 

In comparison, **RAG** (Retrieval-Augmented Generation) also contributes to a notable portion of errors, although it is less prevalent than Reasoning-related issues [6]. The **Step-Back** method itself introduces relatively few errors, as shown in the data where only 4.4% of errors are introduced by Step-Back when combined with RAG [10].

In summary, the main error types in Step-Back Prompting on TimeQA are **Reasoning Error** and **Math Error**, which dominate the error distribution, followed by **RAG** and **Principle Error**.

[1] Training-time correction has been extensively studied and is represented by several key strategies, including Direct Optimization with Human Feedback, Reward Modeling and Reinforcement Learning from Human Feedback (RLHF), and Self-Training. These methods involve using feedback during the training phase to optimize the model parameters. For instance, Direct Optimization with Human Feedback leverages human feedback to fine-tune the model on outputs that receive positive or negative ratings, as described in [5]. Additionally, RLHF, a widely adopted approach, uses human feedback to guide the model's training through reinforcement learning, as mentioned in [7]. ![{Training-time correction strategies and their feedback mechanisms}](image4)  

[6] Generation-time correction focuses on correcting errors during the generation process using automated feedback. This strategy includes methods like Generate-then-Rank and Feedback-Guided Decoding, which are illustrated in [9]. These approaches aim to improve the efficiency and accuracy of output generation by incorporating real-time feedback. ![{Illustration of generation-time correction strategies}](image3)  

[1] Post-hoc correction involves refining the model output after it has been generated without updating the model parameters. It allows for more diverse natural language feedback and is categorized into Self-Correction, Correction with External Feedback, and Multi-Agent Debate, as detailed in [1]. The image below provides an overview of these strategies: ![{Post-hoc correction strategies}](image2)  

Among the three correction strategies—training-time correction, generation-time correction, and post-hoc correction—training-time correction has the most representative papers in the survey due to its foundational role in model development and the extensive research surrounding methods like RLHF and self-training.

The RAR pipeline for multimodal retrieval is structured around two main components: the **Multimodal Retriever** and the **Retrieving & Ranking** process. These components work together to enhance the performance of MLLMs in fine-grained recognition tasks by leveraging both retrieval and ranking mechanisms.

The **Multimodal Retriever** is responsible for querying a large external memory or database to find information relevant to the input query or context. It creates and stores multimodal embeddings for visual images and text descriptions, enabling efficient retrieval of similar results. As shown in Fig. 3, this component uses an index system based on the HNSW (Hierarchical Navigable Small World) algorithm [35] to facilitate fast and accurate retrieval. This indexing technique reduces the dimensionality of the embeddings from $ \mathbb{R}^{d} $ to $ \frac{d}{9} $, significantly improving the speed of the retrieval process while maintaining high accuracy. ![{The multimodal retriever constructs and stores embeddings for efficient retrieval using indexing techniques.}](image3)

Following the retrieval phase, the retrieved category labels alongside image embedding $ e $ are integrated and sent to the MLLMs through a ranking prompt. The **Retrieving & Ranking** process involves using MLLMs to refine and rank these retrieved candidate object categories based on similarity. This step ensures that the final prediction is not only informed by the retrieved information but also enhanced by the MLLMs' internal knowledge. As illustrated in Fig. 4, the ranking prompt guides the MLLMs to sort the retrieved categories, with the most relevant ones appearing at the top. This process enables more accurate and contextually aware classification predictions. ![{The retrieving and ranking process uses MLLMs to refine and rank retrieved categories for accurate classification.}](image4)

By integrating these two components, the RAR pipeline addresses the limitations of MLLMs in fine-grained recognition tasks while preserving their extensive knowledge base. This design allows the system to handle a wide variety of images and categories with high precision and flexibility.

The study explores how LLM reranking impacts micro-F1 performance across different confidence levels, particularly for the FewNERD dataset. According to the text, LLMs are not effective few-shot information extractors in general but can significantly improve performance on hard samples when combined with SLMs [2]. The proposed **filter-then-rerank** paradigm uses SLMs to identify hard samples and reranks them using LLMs, which leads to a consistent F1 gain of 2.4% on average [7].

![{LLM reranking improves micro-F1 on hard samples}](image5)  
The image illustrates the relationship between confidence scores and micro-F1 performance for the FewNERD dataset, comparing results with and without LLM reranking. The graph shows that LLM reranking (blue line) enhances performance on hard samples (lower confidence scores), while it slightly degrades performance on easy samples (higher confidence scores) [9].

The findings suggest that LLM reranking is most beneficial for samples with lower confidence scores, where SLMs struggle, and it contributes to an overall improvement in micro-F1 performance by focusing on challenging cases. This approach effectively leverages the strengths of both SLMs and LLMs to enhance task performance.  

LLM reranking significantly improves micro-F1 performance on hard samples (low confidence levels) for the FewNERD dataset, while it has a minimal negative impact on easy samples.

The SciIE model demonstrates strong performance across various tasks, outperforming other models in precision, recall, and F1 score. For instance, in **span identification**, the SciIE model achieves a precision of 62.2, recall of 55.4, and an F1 score of 58.6, which is better than both Luan 2017 and the best SemEval system [10]. Similarly, in **keyphrase extraction**, the SciIE model shows a precision of 48.5 and recall of 43.8, resulting in an F1 score of 46.0, surpassing the results of Luan 2017 [image1].

In **relation extraction**, the SciIE model reaches a precision of 40.4 and a recall of 21.2, achieving an F1 score of 27.8, which is competitive with the state-of-the-art systems [image1]. Furthermore, the multitask approach of SciIE significantly improves performance across all tasks, as evidenced by its superior scores compared to single-task models [image2]. Specifically, in entity recognition, SciIE attains an F1 score of 68.1 on the development set and 64.2 on the test set, while in relation extraction, it achieves F1 scores of 39.5 (development) and 39.3 (test). For coreference resolution, SciIE reaches an F1 score of 58.0 on the development set and 48.2 on the test set [image3].

Coreference has a notable impact on the performance of the SciIE model. The precision/recall curves show that incorporating coreference links significantly enhances the quality of the knowledge graph, with the curve for "With Coreference" consistently performing better than "Without Coreference." The AUC for the curve with coreference is 0.751, compared to 0.695 without coreference, indicating a clear improvement [image4]. This suggests that coreference resolution plays a crucial role in enhancing the overall effectiveness of the model.

The SciIE model performs better than other models in terms of precision, recall, and F1 score across different tasks, and coreference significantly enhances its performance.

The weight in the Weighted Decoding Response table influences the model's output by altering the emphasis on specific aspects of the response generation. As shown in the table, different weights lead to varying responses and changes in the Normalized Inverse Document Frequency (NIDF), which reflects the uniqueness or informativeness of the generated text.

For instance, at a weight of -5.0, the response is "Oh......................................" with an NIDF of 0.6%, indicating a very generic or nonsensical output. At weight 0.0, the response matches the baseline: "That sounds like a lot of fun!" with an NIDF of 17.1%, suggesting a standard, unaltered response. Increasing the weight to 3.0 introduces a question, resulting in "That sounds like a lot of fun. How long have you been studying?" with an NIDF of 18.3%. Further increasing the weight to 7.0 leads to a more unique but potentially less coherent response: "I majored in practising my spiritual full-time philosophy test" with an NIDF of 38.5%. At the highest weight of 10.0, the response becomes highly unique and possibly nonsensical: "Oh wow! Merna jean isa paino yi hao hui bu acara sya gila [...]" with an NIDF of 71.9%.

This demonstrates that higher weights can increase the uniqueness of the response but may also reduce its coherence or appropriateness, as noted in [2]. The balance between these factors is crucial for generating meaningful and contextually appropriate dialogue.

![{The weighted decoding process affects the uniqueness and coherence of generated responses based on the assigned weight.}](image5)

According to Figure 1, each word in a sentence is first represented by its **word embedding**, as shown in the diagram. This representation captures the semantic meaning of the word in a dense vector space. Once the word embeddings are obtained, they are input into **bi-directional LSTM layers** (LSTM-F and LSTM-B), which process the sequence of words in both forward and backward directions. This bidirectional processing allows the model to capture contextual information from both previous and subsequent words, enhancing the understanding of the word's role within the sentence. The outputs from these LSTM layers are then used to predict the final entity labels for each word through a **CRF layer**. ![{Each word is represented by its word embedding and processed through bi-directional LSTM layers before label prediction}](image4)

The introduction of Retrieval Augmentation (RA) significantly enhances the accuracy and reduces hallucination rates across different entity categories—Head, Torso, and Tail. As depicted in the table shown in image4, the impact is particularly pronounced for long-tail entities. 

![{The table illustrates the improvement in accuracy and reduction in hallucination rates with Retrieval Augmentation across Head, Torso, and Tail categories}](image4)

For **Head** entities, RA leads to an increase in accuracy from 24.4% to 27.1%, a 11.1% improvement, while the hallucination rate decreases from 75.6% to 72.9%, a 3.6% reduction. For **Torso** entities, accuracy improves more notably, rising from 19.1% to 22.7%, a 18.8% increase, and the hallucination rate drops from 80.9% to 77.3%, a 4.4% decrease. The most significant enhancement is observed in **Tail** entities, where accuracy jumps from 6.8% to 12.6%, an 85.3% increase, and the hallucination rate declines from 93.2% to 87.4%, a 6.2% reduction. These results underscore the effectiveness of RA in addressing the challenges posed by long-tail entities, thereby improving the reliability and accuracy of responses in entity-centric VQA tasks.

The triplet margin loss in the Translation Ranking model, as shown in Figure 2, is used to optimize the embedding space such that the "better" hypothesis is mapped closer to the "anchors" (source and reference) while keeping the "worse" hypothesis farther away. This ensures that the model learns to distinguish between high-quality and low-quality translations based on their semantic similarity to the reference and source texts. 

![{The triplet margin loss optimizes the embedding space to minimize the distance between the "better" hypothesis and the "anchors" (source and reference), while maximizing the distance between the "worse" hypothesis and the anchors.}](image3) 

This approach helps improve the correlation between the model's predictions and human judgments of translation quality.

The 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy enhances the refinement of outputs by incorporating external models or tools to provide additional feedback beyond what the critic model alone can offer. This approach allows for more comprehensive and diverse feedback, which can include insights from knowledge bases, trained models, code interpreters, and search engines. As described in the image, this strategy involves the language model generating outputs, a critic model reviewing them, and then external models or tools assisting in refining the outputs further. ![{Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback}](image1)  

This method leverages external resources to address specific issues such as factual accuracy, logical consistency, and quality improvements. For instance, external knowledge sources like Wikipedia or the internet can be used to verify the correctness of generated content, ensuring that the final output is both accurate and reliable. Additionally, the use of trained models or program executors can help in evaluating the technical correctness of outputs, especially in tasks like code generation or mathematical reasoning. ![{Automated Feedback Framework}](image2)  

By integrating these external feedback mechanisms, the refinement process becomes more robust and adaptable, allowing the model to incorporate a wider range of perspectives and corrections. This leads to higher-quality outputs that are more aligned with the desired goals of the task, whether it be improving factual accuracy, reducing toxicity, or enhancing narrative coherence. The iterative nature of this strategy ensures that each refinement step contributes to a more polished and accurate final result.  

In summary, the 'Post-hoc Correction with External Feedback' strategy enhances output refinement by utilizing external models and tools to provide diverse, detailed, and accurate feedback, thereby improving the overall quality and reliability of the generated text.
