The Tree Traversal Retrieval and Collapsed Tree Retrieval methods differ in their approach to retrieving information from a hierarchical tree structure. Tree Traversal Retrieval processes the tree layer-by-layer, starting from the root and selecting the top-k most relevant nodes at each level based on cosine similarity to the query vector. This method progressively narrows down the search, focusing on finer details as it moves through the tree layers [7]. In contrast, Collapsed Tree Retrieval evaluates all nodes simultaneously across all layers, flattening the multi-layered tree into a single layer for comparison. This allows the retrieval process to consider information at various levels of granularity simultaneously, which can better match the required detail level for a given question [3].

![{Tree Traversal and Collapsed Tree Retrieval methods}](image2)  

As illustrated in the image, both methods begin with encoding the query into a vector, but they diverge in how they handle the tree structure. Tree Traversal follows a sequential path through the tree, while Collapsed Tree collapses the structure into one layer, enabling a more flexible and comprehensive search [8]. The collapsed tree approach is noted for its ability to retrieve information that aligns with the correct level of granularity for the question, offering greater flexibility compared to the fixed ratio of node levels seen in tree traversal [1].

In terms of performance, the collapsed tree method has been shown to consistently outperform tree traversal in controlled experiments, particularly in tasks requiring complex reasoning and multi-hop question answering [1]. The effectiveness of these methods is further supported by empirical results, such as the significant improvements observed when using RAPTOR with collapsed tree retrieval on the QuALITY benchmark, where performance increased by 20% in absolute accuracy [6].

The difference in their approaches directly impacts the quality and relevance of the retrieved context, making the choice between them dependent on the specific requirements of the task.

[1] According to the text, the SWEM model demonstrates stronger performance on topic prediction tasks compared to both LSTM and CNN compositional architectures. Specifically, the SWEM- concat model even outperforms a 29-layer deep CNN model (Conneau et al., 2016) when predicting topics. However, this statement refers to topic categorization rather than sentiment analysis.

[2] The text also mentions that on the Yelp Polarity dataset, SWEM shows significantly higher accuracy than CNN for a large range of low subspace dimension, indicating that SWEM is more parameter-efficient to get a decent solution. This suggests that SWEM performs well on sentiment analysis tasks, including Yelp Polarity.

[4] In the context of sentiment analysis datasets, SWEM yields inferior accuracies compared to CNN/LSTM compositional functions. This indicates that SWEM may not be as effective at extracting representations from short sentences as it is from long documents. However, it still exhibits comparable performance on other tasks with much fewer parameters and faster training.

[5] The SWEM- hier variant greatly outperforms the other three SWEM variants, and the corresponding accuracies are comparable to the results of CNN or LSTM (Table 2). This indicates that the hierarchical pooling operation manages to abstract spatial (word-order) information from the input sequence, which is beneficial for performance in sentiment analysis tasks.

[7] Surprisingly, on most of the datasets considered (except WikiQA), SWEM demonstrates the best results compared with those with CNN or the LSTM encoder. Notably, on the SNLI dataset, we observe that SWEM- max performs the best among all SWEM variants, consistent with the findings in Nie and Bansal (2017); Conneau et al. (2017), that max-pooling over BiLSTM hidden units outperforms average pooling operation on SNLI dataset. As a result, with only 120K parameters, our SWEM- max achieves a test accuracy of 83.8%, which is very competitive among state-of-the-art sentence encoding-based models (in terms of both performance and number of parameters).

[8] For the sentiment analysis tasks, both CNN and LSTM compositional functions perform better than SWEM, suggesting that word-order information may be required for analyzing sentiment orientations. This finding is consistent with Pang et al. (2002), where they hypothesize that the positional information of a word in text sequences may be beneficial to predict sentiment. This is intuitively reasonable since, for instance, the phrase “not really good” and “really not good” convey different levels of negative sentiment, while being different only by their word orderings. Contrary to SWEM, CNN and LSTM models can both capture this type of information via convolutional filters or recurrent transition functions.

[9] We have also tried our SWEM-concat and SWEM-hier models on Sogou news corpus (with the same experimental setup as (Zhang et al., 2015b)), which is a Chinese dataset represented by Pinyin (a phonetic romanization of Chinese). SWEM-concat yields an accuracy of 91.3%, while SWEM-hier (with a local window size of 5) obtains an accuracy of 96.2% on the test set. Notably, the performance of SWEM-hier is comparable to the best accuracies of CNN (95.6%) and LSTM (95.2%), as reported in (Zhang et al., 2015b). This indicates that hierarchical pooling is more suitable than average/max pooling for Chinese text classification, by taking spatial information into account. It also implies that Chinese is more sensitive to local word-order features than English.

The Uyghur Named Entity Recognition (NER) task presents a unique challenge due to the limited availability of annotated data. To address this, researchers have explored cross-lingual and unsupervised transfer methods, leveraging resources such as bilingual dictionaries, word embeddings, and self-attention mechanisms. The performance of these models is often evaluated using various configurations and additional resources, including parallel corpora, Wikipedia, and different-sized dictionaries.

![{Our method achieves the best results when combined with external resources and self-attention}](image2)

In the context of the Uyghur NER task, the model that performs best across different resources is the **combined approach** that integrates **word embeddings**, **self-attention**, and **external resources** like **Wikipedia** and **dictionaries**. This method outperforms other approaches, achieving an $F_1$ score of 32.09 ± 0.61, as shown in Table 2. The success of this method is attributed to its ability to leverage both high-quality translations of named entities and contextual information through self-attention, which enhances the model's robustness to word order differences and lexical gaps.

This combined approach demonstrates superior performance compared to methods that rely solely on dictionary-based translation or lack the use of self-attention, highlighting the importance of integrating multiple resources and advanced architectural components for low-resource languages like Uyghur.

The DETR model utilizes object queries as a fundamental component of its architecture, enabling it to perform direct set prediction for object detection. These object queries are learned positional encodings that serve as input embeddings for the transformer decoder. As described in [5], these $N$ object queries are transformed into output embeddings through the decoder, which then independently decodes each embedding into box coordinates and class labels via a feed forward network. This process allows the model to generate $N$ final predictions in parallel, effectively reasoning about all objects together using pairwise relations between them and the global image context.

![{object queries are learned positional encodings used as input embeddings for the transformer decoder in DETR}](image3)

Unlike traditional detection methods that rely on hand-designed components such as anchors or non-maximal suppression, DETR simplifies the pipeline by leveraging the permutation-invariant nature of the decoder. The object queries are crucial in this setup because they provide the initial input for the decoder, allowing it to produce unique predictions without requiring explicit post-processing steps [1]. 

Additionally, the use of object queries enables the model to handle the set prediction task efficiently, as highlighted in [9], where the self-attention mechanisms of the transformer explicitly model all pairwise interactions between elements in a sequence, making them particularly suitable for set prediction tasks like object detection.

In summary, the DETR model utilizes object queries as learned positional encodings that guide the transformer decoder in generating final object predictions.

The table shows that fine-tuning the RAR method with InternLM-XC2 consistently achieves higher performance compared to in-context learning strategies across various datasets. The green-highlighted values indicate superior results for the fine-tuned approach, demonstrating its reliability and effectiveness.

[7] In-Context Learning for Ranking. In-context learning presents a valuable alternative to fine-tuning with ranking examples, particularly due to its flexibility and lower requirement for specialized data preparation. While fine-tuning with ranking examples has proven to be highly effective, it necessitates a substantial amount of curated data and computational resources for training. In contrast, in-context learning uses the model’s existing knowledge by providing it with specific examples directly within the input prompt, guiding the model to understand and execute the task of ranking without the need for explicit re-training. Here we elaborate on the application of in-context learning with MLLMs to rank the retrieved results. To effectively guide the MLLMs in comprehending the ranking task, we use the prompt format similar to Fig. 4 and integrate a specific ranking example into the prompts. Please refer to the Appendix B for our structured in-context learning prompt. Please refer to Sec. 4.5 for the ablation studies of discussing the difference between using fine-tuning or in-context learning for ranking.

[8] To create our fine-tuning data, we use the CLIP image encoder $\varPhi_{\mathrm{img}}$ to extract the embeddings of two disjoint subsets of images $\mathcal{D}_{a}$ and $\mathcal{D}_{b}$, both drawn from the FGVC-Aircraft dataset. We provide the ablation studies in Sec. 4.5 about using different datasets to construct the fine-tuning data. Our observation reveals that the MLLM demonstrates robustness to the choice of fine-tuning datasets, with only marginal differences in performance outcomes.

[5] Tab. 6 presents the results. We observe that RAR is not sensitive to changes in the fine-tuning dataset for ranking, thereby confirming its viability as a generalizable and reliable method for enhancing the performance of MLLMs. The consistency in results, irrespective of the fine-tuning data source, underlines the robustness of our fine-tuning strategy. Despite these minor variations, the overall performance of using FGVC-Aircrafts (82.7 % , top row) is higher than using Stanford Cars (82.0 % , second row) for QWen-VL, and we observe the same trend.

[9] Comparison with Rare Classes Results ($\mathbf{A}\mathbf{P_{r}}$). We find an interesting observation from the experimental results presented in Tab. 3. For the CLIP model, we observe a progressive increase in performance from $\mathrm{AP_{r}}$ through AP $\mathrm{c}$ to AP $^\dag$, which indicates a gradation in precision across varying class frequencies. However, employing our method yields a different trend, where the peak performance is achieved on $A P_{r}$, surpassing the CLIP model by as much as 19.6 percentage points. This significant leap in performance suggests a substantial advantage of our method when it comes to rare categories. The integration of our RAR to MLLMs plays a pivotal role here, as it demonstrates a heightened ability to discriminate among the rare classes. Our observation could be attributed to the fact that our retrieving and reranking mechanism effectively pools relevant information from the external memory, providing the MLLMs with a richer context for rare class identification. Moreover, the ranking capability of MLLMs ensures that even the lesser-represented classes receive adequate attention during the classification process. Our RAR achieves a robust enhancement in the model’s ability to discern and accurately classify objects that are infrequently encountered, addressing one of the significant challenges in long-tailed distribution datasets.

Fine-tuning the RAR method with the InternLM-XC2 model consistently outperforms in-context learning across different datasets, as evidenced by the higher accuracy and robustness observed in the experimental results.

To determine the average performance gap between the ProgramFC and our proposed QACHECK system on the HOVER dataset, we need to compare their respective scores for the 2-hop, 3-hop, and 4-hop claims. 

From the data provided:
- **ProgramFC** scores are: 54.27 (2-hop), 54.18 (3-hop), and 52.88 (4-hop).
- **QACHECK** scores are: 55.67 (2-hop), 54.67 (3-hop), and 52.35 (4-hop).

Calculating the differences:
- 2-hop: $ 55.67 - 54.27 = 1.40 $
- 3-hop: $ 54.67 - 54.18 = 0.49 $
- 4-hop: $ 52.35 - 52.88 = -0.53 $

The negative value for the 4-hop indicates that QACHECK performed slightly worse than ProgramFC in this category. To find the average performance gap, we take the absolute values of these differences and compute the mean:

$$
\text{Average Performance Gap} = \frac{|1.40| + |0.49| + |-0.53|}{3} = \frac{1.40 + 0.49 + 0.53}{3} = \frac{2.42}{3} = 0.81
$$

![{The table presents the performance comparison of different AI models on the HOVER dataset.}](image3)

The Sythus process for generating instruction-response pairs involves a structured and iterative approach to ensure high-quality, multi-lingual outputs. It begins with **Step 1: System Message + Visual Annotation**, where a system message is defined to guide the tone and style of the generated pairs, and visual annotations provide essential image details such as bounding boxes and descriptions. ![{A flowchart illustrating the Sythus process for generating instruction-response pairs in eight languages}](image1)

Following this, the **Cold Start** phase identifies the best system message and in-context example, which are crucial for querying instruction-response pairs from a dataset. This stage ensures that the initial examples used for training are of high quality before scaling up to large-scale data collection.

In **Step 2: Generate Instruction-Response Pairs**, ChatGPT is utilized to create these pairs based on the visual context, including timestamps, captions, and object information. The process leverages both the system message and visual annotations to guide the generation of meaningful instructions and responses.

To maintain quality, **Step 3: Filtering** is implemented, where ChatGPT is again used to evaluate and refine the generated pairs, ensuring they meet the required standards for accuracy and relevance. Finally, in **Step 4: Translation**, the instruction-response pairs are translated into eight languages—English, Chinese, Spanish, Japanese, French, German, Korean, and Arabic—to support multi-lingual usage.

This systematic pipeline enables the creation of diverse and high-quality instruction-response pairs tailored for vision-language models, enhancing their capabilities in perception, reasoning, and planning.

The Translation Ranking model, as depicted in Figure 2, receives as input a tuple $\chi = (s, h^{+}, h^{-}, r)$, where $s$ denotes the source text, $h^{+}$ is an hypothesis ranked higher than another hypothesis $h^{-}$, and $r$ represents the reference translation. This input structure allows the model to compare different hypotheses against both the source and the reference, facilitating the ranking of translation quality based on human judgments.

![{Translation Ranking model input structure}](image4) 

This architecture enables the model to optimize the embedding space using the triplet margin loss, ensuring that the "better" hypothesis is closer to the anchor (source and reference) in the embedding space. The model's design reflects a focus on capturing the nuances of translation quality by incorporating both the source and reference texts alongside the hypotheses being evaluated. 

The inputs to the Translation Ranking model are therefore the source text, the better hypothesis, the worse hypothesis, and the reference translation.

The anchor-only context compression technique significantly accelerates the inference process for GPT2-XL. As indicated in Table 3, the speed-up ratio for the AGNews dataset with GPT2-XL is **2.5×**, demonstrating a substantial efficiency gain through this method. This acceleration is attributed to the reduced input context length, which minimizes computational overhead while maintaining high performance. The effectiveness of this approach is further supported by the observation that longer demonstration lengths tend to yield higher acceleration ratios, as noted in [2]. 

![{The table compares performance metrics for two models, GPT2-XL and GPT-J, across four datasets: SST-2, TREC, AGNews, and EmoC. The values are as follows: GPT2-XL: SST-2: 1.1×, TREC: 1.5×, AGNews: 2.5×, EmoC: 1.4×; GPT-J: SST-2: 1.5×, TREC: 2.2×, AGNews: 2.9×, EmoC: 1.9×.}](image1) 

The results highlight that the compression method introduces negligible information loss, as evidenced by the minimal accuracy drop (1.5% for GPT-J) compared to the uncompressed scenario [6]. Additionally, the hypothesis that label words act as anchors in in-context learning is validated through various experiments, including the proposed anchor re-weighting method and demonstration compression techniques [7]. 

In summary, using anchor-only context compression, GPT2-XL can achieve a **2.5× speed-up** on the AGNews dataset.

[1] The presence of repetition control significantly affects the frequency of question-asking in generated text. As noted in the text, when repetition control is introduced, question-asking is reduced—specifically, the $z=10$ setting, which should produce $100\%$ questions, only produces $79.67\%$ questions. This reduction is primarily due to the weighted decoding feature `extrep bigram`, which discourages bigrams that have appeared in previous utterances, thereby preventing the model from producing common question-starting bigrams like "do you" and "what is" [3]. To address this issue, an additional setting $z=10 (boost)$ was introduced, where the model does not use the `extrep bigram` during beam search but uses it to rerank candidates after beam search, resulting in a $99.54\%$ question-asking rate [3].

![{reduction in question-asking with repetition control}](image4)  
The image illustrates how different methods control the frequency of question-asking in generated text. The **Question-controlled CT with repetition control** (purple line with squares) shows a more gradual increase in the percentage of questions compared to **Question-controlled CT** (blue line with circles), which approaches near 100% at higher control levels. This visual representation highlights the dampening effect of repetition control on question-asking frequency.

[2] Furthermore, the study found that conditional training is preferable to weighted decoding for controlling question-asking because it allows precise control over the proportion of questions without introducing degenerate outputs. This method enables the model to achieve a wide range of question-asking rates, from $0\%$ to $100\%$, depending on the control variable $z$ [10].

[3] In summary, the presence of repetition control reduces the frequency of question-asking in generated text by discouraging the use of common question-starting bigrams. However, this effect can be mitigated through adjustments in the decoding process, such as the $z=10 (boost)$ setting, which allows the model to maintain high question-asking rates while still applying repetition control [3].

[4] The two methods introduced in Figure 3, LSTUR-ini and LSTUR-con, differ in how they integrate the long-term and short-term user representations. ![{The two methods for integrating long-term and short-term user representations}](image3)  
The first method, LSTUR-ini, uses the long-term user representation to initialize the hidden state of the GRU network in the short-term user representation model. This initialization allows the model to leverage the long-term preferences as a starting point for capturing recent user interests. In contrast, the second method, LSTUR-con, concatenates the long-term and short-term user representations directly to form a unified user vector. This approach retains all information from both representations without relying on initialization, providing a more comprehensive integration of user behavior over time. Both methods aim to enhance the accuracy of news recommendations by combining historical and recent user interests, with LSTUR-con showing greater stability in performance [5].

Recursive retrieval involves a structured index to process and retrieve data in a hierarchical manner, which may include summarizing sections of a document or lengthy PDF before performing a retrieval based on this summary. Subsequently, a secondary retrieval within the document refines the search, embodying the recursive nature of the process [5]. ![{Recursive retrieval process}](image5)  
Iterative retrieval alternates between retrieval and generation, aiming to provide richer and more targeted context from the knowledge base at each step. It iterates a specified number of times or until a threshold is met. The process follows a sequence: Query → Retrieve → Generate → Judge → (Repeat or Response) [5]. ![{Iterative retrieval process}](image5)  
Adaptive retrieval enables the RAG system to decide when external knowledge retrieval is needed. It can autonomously determine when to stop retrieval and generation, using special tokens. The process begins with a query, followed by a judgment, then retrieval (on demand), generation, query transformation, and another judgment, repeating as necessary. ![{Adaptive retrieval process}](image5)  
The Iterative, Recursive, and Adaptive retrieval processes differ in their approach to enhancing the retrieval and generation tasks, with Iterative focusing on repeated cycles of retrieval and generation, Recursive refining queries and solving complex problems through hierarchical refinement, and Adaptive enabling the system to autonomously decide when to retrieve and generate based on context and needs.

[5] We explore how various decoding schemes affect the quality of candidate knowledge tuples. We present the effect of the following generation strategies: argmax greedy decoding, beam search with beam sizes, $\tt b=2$, 5, 10, and top-$\cdot k$ sampling with $\mathbf{k}=5$, 10. For each decoding method, we conduct the human evaluation on the number of final candidates produced by each method.  
[6] While producing more total candidates does lower overall performance, the results still hover around $55\%^{7}$ for a beam size of 10. This result suggests that COMET could be effective with human evaluators in the loop to confirm the correctness of generated tuples.  
[10] Empirical results on two commonsense knowledge bases, A TOMIC and ConceptNet, show that COMET frequently produces novel commonsense knowledge that human evaluators deem to be correct. These positive results point to future work in extending the approach to a variety of other types of knowledge bases, as well as investigating whether COMET can learn to produce OpenIE-style knowledge tuples for arbitrary knowledge seeds.  
[9] Our findings suggest that using generative commonsense models for automatic commonsense KB completion could soon be a plausible alternative to extractive methods.

The inclusion of gold paragraphs and distractors significantly impacts the F1 scores in multi-hop question answering models, as demonstrated by the experimental results. When gold paragraphs are included alongside distractors, the model's performance improves substantially. For instance, in the open-domain setting, the F1 score increases from 39.12 (with 500 retrieved paragraphs) to 53.12 when additional gold paragraphs are provided [10]. This highlights the critical role of retrieving accurate and relevant information for multi-hop reasoning tasks.

![{The F1 scores for different settings show that including gold paragraphs in an open-domain setting significantly improves model performance.}](image5)

Furthermore, the presence of distractors can challenge the model's ability to distinguish between relevant and irrelevant information. In the distractor setting, the single-paragraph BERT model achieves an F1 score of 67.08, which is comparable to state-of-the-art models [1]. However, when the model is tested on adversarial distractors, its performance drops to 46.84 F1, indicating that the quality and selection of distractors play a crucial role in evaluating model robustness [4].

![{The table shows how model performance varies based on the type of training and evaluation data, with adversarial distractors leading to a significant drop in accuracy.}](image2)

In contrast, when the model is retrained on adversarial distractors, it recovers most of its original accuracy, reaching 60.10 F1 on adversarial distractors [4]. This suggests that while distractors can be challenging, they also provide valuable opportunities for improving model generalization and robustness.

Additionally, the analysis reveals that the effectiveness of distractors depends on their selection method. Standard TF-IDF retrieval often fails to retrieve gold paragraphs, especially in open-domain settings, where the model struggles to achieve high F1 scores without access to the correct information [10]. This underscores the need for improved retrieval methods tailored for multi-hop questions.

![{The table compares F1 scores across various models under different evaluation settings, showing that some models perform better in open-domain scenarios when gold paragraphs are included.}](image3)

In conclusion, the inclusion of gold paragraphs enhances model performance, while the use of well-curated distractors presents both challenges and opportunities for improving multi-hop reasoning capabilities. The implications for model performance highlight the importance of developing more effective retrieval strategies and adversarial training techniques to enhance robustness and accuracy in complex question-answering tasks.

The components marked as 'Word LSTM-B' and 'Word LSTM-F' in Figure 4 are part of a neural network architecture designed for named entity recognition (NER). These components function similarly to the character-level LSTMs but operate at the word level. 

The **Word LSTM-B** (Backward) processes the sequence of word representations from right to left, capturing contextual information that may be relevant for understanding the meaning of words in relation to their subsequent context. The **Word LSTM-F** (Forward) processes the sequence from left to right, capturing contextual information based on preceding words. Together, these bidirectional LSTMs allow the model to capture both forward and backward contextual dependencies at the word level, which is crucial for accurately identifying and labeling named entities in text.

![{The diagram illustrates a neural network model for named entity recognition using a combination of character-level and word-level representations.}](image5)

Moreover, COMET generates **novel tuples** with **59.25%** not present in the training set, showing its ability to create new edges and even new nodes in the knowledge graph [6]. In terms of metrics such as **perplexity (PPL)**, **BLEU-2**, and **N/U o**, COMET outperforms other models, including **9ENC9DEC**, **Event2(IN)VOLUN**, and others [5], [10]. Specifically, COMET achieves a **PPL of 11.14**, which is significantly lower than other models like **COMET (- pretrain)** [5], and a **BLEU-2 score of 15.10**, the highest among all models [5].

Finally, the table in **image3** confirms that COMET has the **lowest perplexity (4.32)**, the **highest score (95.25%)**, and the **closest approximation to human performance (91.69%)** across various metrics [3]. This further solidifies COMET's position as the model with the best overall performance in generating ConceptNet tuples.

[2] The document-cue baseline can predict more than a third of the samples correctly, for both datasets, even after sub-sampling frequent document-answer pairs for WIKI HOP. The relative strength of this and other baselines proves to be an important issue when designing multi-hop datasets, which we addressed through the measures described in Section 3.2. In Table 4 we compare the two relevant baselines on WIKI HOP before and after applying filtering measures. The absolute strength of these baselines before filtering shows how vital addressing this issue is: $74.6\%$ accuracy could be reached through exploiting the cooccurrence $(d,c)$ statistic alone. This underlines the paramount importance of investigating and addressing dataset biases that otherwise would confound seemingly strong RC model performance. The relative drop demonstrates that ![{The table shows the performance comparison of different models on WIKIHOP before and after filtering, with the document-cue model achieving 74.6% accuracy before filtering and a reduced score after filtering.}](image2) 

[9] The TF-IDF retrieval baseline clearly performs better than random for WIKI HOP, but is not very strong overall. That is, the question tokens are helpful to detect relevant documents, but exploiting only this information compares poorly to the other baselines. On the other hand, as no co-mention of an interacting drug pair occurs within any single document in MED HOP, the TF-IDF baseline performs worse than random. We conclude that lexical matching with a single support document is not enough to build a strong predictive model for both datasets.

[3] Most Reading Comprehension methods limit themselves to queries which can be answered using a single sentence, paragraph, or document. Enabling models to combine disjoint pieces of textual evidence would extend the scope of machine comprehension methods, but currently no resources exist to train and test this capability. We propose a novel task to encourage the development of models for text understanding across multiple documents and to investigate the limits of existing methods. In our task, a model learns to seek and combine evidence – effectively performing multi-hop, alias multi-step, inference. We devise a methodology to produce datasets for this task, given a collection of query-answer pairs and thematically linked documents. Two datasets from different domains are induced, and we identify potential pitfalls and devise circumvention strategies. We evaluate two previously proposed competitive models and find that one can integrate information across documents. However, both models struggle to select relevant information; and providing documents guaranteed to be relevant greatly improves their performance. While the models outperform several strong baselines, their best accuracy reaches $54.5\%$ on an annotated test set, compared to human performance at $85.0\%$, leaving ample room for improvement.

[7] We conducted further experiments to examine the RC models when presented with only the relevant documents in $S_{q}$, i.e., the chain of documents leading to the correct answer. This allows us to investigate the hypothetical performance of the models if they were able to select and read only relevant documents: Table 6 summarizes these results. Models improve greatly in this gold chain setup, with up to $81.2\%~/~85.7\%$ on WIKI HOP in the masked setting for BiDAF. This demonstrates that RC models are capable of identifying the answer when few or no plausible false candidates are mentioned, which is particularly evident for MED HOP, where documents tend to discuss only single drug candidates. In the masked gold chain setup, models can then pick up on what the masking template looks like and achieve almost perfect scores. Conversely, these results also show that the models’ answer selection process is not robust to the introduction of unrelated documents with type-consistent candidates. This indicates that learning to intelligently select relevant documents before RC may be among the most promising directions for future model development.

The document-cue model's accuracy on WIKIHOP was significantly higher before filtering, reaching $74.6\%$, but dropped considerably after filtering measures were applied, highlighting the importance of addressing dataset biases.

[2] The performance of LSTM on sentiment analysis tasks is notably better than SWEM, suggesting that word-order information plays a crucial role in capturing the nuances of sentiment. For instance, phrases like “not really good” and “really not good” convey different levels of negative sentiment, and LSTM models can capture such differences through their recurrent transition functions. This aligns with the hypothesis that positional information of words in text sequences is beneficial for predicting sentiment. ![{LSTM outperforms SWEM in sentiment analysis due to word-order sensitivity}](image1)

[6] When word-order information is disrupted by shuffling the training set, the accuracy on sentiment analysis tasks, such as Yelp polarity, drops significantly. This further supports the idea that word-order features are essential for sentiment analysis, as they contribute to the model's ability to understand the context and nuance of the text. ![{Shuffling training data reduces sentiment analysis accuracy}](image1)

[3] To investigate the importance of word-order information, the authors shuffled the words in the training set while keeping the test set in its original form. This approach helps isolate the impact of word-order on model performance. LSTM, which is capable of capturing word-order information, was used for this purpose, highlighting its sensitivity to such features. ![{Shuffling training data isolates word-order effects}](image1)

[10] In contrast to sentiment analysis, where word-order information is critical, SWEM performs comparably or even better on other tasks like topic categorization and textual entailment. This suggests that while word-order features are important for sentiment analysis, they may be less relevant for other NLP tasks. ![{SWEM performs well on tasks less reliant on word-order}](image1)

[4] While SWEM demonstrates strong performance on tasks like sentence matching, it is not as effective as LSTM in sentiment analysis, which relies heavily on word-order information. This highlights the importance of modeling word-order in tasks where sentiment orientation is key. ![{SWEM vs. LSTM performance across tasks}](image3) 

In summary, word-order information significantly affects sentiment analysis accuracy in LSTM models, as these models are designed to capture sequential dependencies that are crucial for understanding nuanced sentiment expressions.

The distribution of query types across the three rungs in the dataset is illustrated through a circular chart, which categorizes queries into three main sections corresponding to Rung 1, Rung 2, and Rung 3. ![{distribution of query types across three rungs}](image3) 

Rung 1 is primarily composed of probabilistic queries such as conditional probability and marginal probability. Rung 2 includes causal inference queries like Average Treatment Effect (ATE) and adjustment set. Rung 3 encompasses more complex causal reasoning queries including counterfactuals, natural direct effect (NDE), natural indirect effect (NIE), and average treatment effect on the treated (ATT). This structure reflects an increasing complexity from basic probabilistic queries to advanced causal reasoning tasks. The dataset is balanced across these query types, with each type represented in the dataset as described in the text [5].

The 'Hard-to-Contrast' method demonstrates superior performance compared to other selection strategies in terms of AUC with varying numbers of labeled images. This is evident from the results presented in multiple figures and tables, which consistently show that the 'Hard-to-Contrast' strategy outperforms alternatives such as Random, Entropy, Margin, BALD, and Coreset. For instance, on PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, and BloodMNIST, the 'Hard-to-Contrast' method achieves significant improvements in AUC scores, with gains of 1.8%, 2.6%, and 5.2%, respectively, when querying only 0.1% of the entire dataset. Similarly, on CIFAR-10-LT, it outperforms other strategies by 21.2% and 24.1% when querying 20% and 30% of the dataset, respectively. These results are further supported by the strong positive correlation between the initial and final AUC scores for the 'Hard-to-Contrast' method, indicating consistent performance improvement over active learning cycles.

The Translation Ranking model processes its inputs by receiving a tuple $\chi = (s, h^+, h^-, r)$, where $s$ is the source text, $h^+$ is a hypothesis ranked higher than $h^-$, and $r$ is the reference translation. These segments are independently encoded using a pretrained cross-lingual encoder, followed by a pooling layer to create sentence embeddings for each segment. ![{Translation Ranking model architecture}](image2) The model then uses the triplet margin loss to optimize the embedding space, minimizing the distance between the "better" hypothesis ($h^+$) and the "anchors" (source $s$ and reference $r$). This ensures that the model learns to distinguish between high-quality and low-quality translations effectively.

In conclusion, the inclusion of a 'Gold Paragraph' in open-domain settings significantly boosts the F1 score, highlighting the importance of effective retrieval methods for multi-hop questions.

The paper describes the construction of causal graphs used in the CL ADDER dataset, which includes various types of structures such as confounding, mediation, collision, diamond, chain, and fork. Specifically, the "chain" type is mentioned as one of the common graph structures used to illustrate toy problems in causal inference.

A chain-type causal graph typically consists of three nodes connected in a linear sequence, where each node points to the next. This structure implies two directed edges: one from the first node to the second, and another from the second node to the third. 

![{A chain-type causal graph has two directed edges connecting three nodes in a linear sequence.}](image1)

The dataset used in this paper that was proposed in 2022 and includes all logical reasoning problems as multiple-choice questions with 5 options is **AR-LSAT**. This dataset collects analytical logic reasoning questions from the Law School Admission Test from 1991 to 2016, and it is particularly challenging, with state-of-the-art models achieving performance only slightly better than random guessing [7]. 

![{AR-LSAT dataset with 5 options}](image4)

The model that performs the best on CL ADDER is **C AUSAL C O T**, achieving an accuracy of **70.40%**, which is **8.37 points better than vanilla GPT-4** [5]. This significant improvement highlights the effectiveness of the C AUSAL C O T prompting strategy in enhancing causal reasoning capabilities across different levels of difficulty, including anti-common sensical and nonsensical data [6]. 

![{Causal reasoning performance comparison}](image4)  
The table in image4 clearly demonstrates that C AUSAL C O T outperforms all other models, including GPT-4, across various categories such as overall accuracy and performance by rung. Additionally, it shows substantial improvements on anti-common sensical and nonsensical data, indicating its strength in handling unseen and complex reasoning tasks.

Moreover, C AUSAL C O T achieves the highest performance across all three rungs of causal questions, with a monotonically decreasing performance as the rungs get higher, i.e., the questions get more difficult [7]. This suggests that the model not only excels in easier tasks but also maintains strong performance on more challenging ones.

In conclusion, **C AUSAL C O T performs the best on CL ADDER**.

The introduction of repetition control significantly affects the question-asking rate at the highest control level (z=10). As noted in [4], without repetition control, the question-asking rate for z=10 is expected to be 100%, but with repetition control, it drops to 79.67%. This reduction is primarily due to the weighted decoding feature "extrep bigram," which discourages the repetition of bigrams from previous utterances. This feature prevents the model from generating common question-starting bigrams like "do you" and "what is." To address this issue, an additional setting $ z = 10 $ (boost) is introduced, where the feature "extrep bigram" is not used during beam search but is used to rerank candidates after beam search. This adjustment allows the model to produce necessary question-asking bigrams, resulting in a question-asking rate of 99.54%, albeit with slightly increased external bigram repetition.

![{The introduction of repetition control reduces the question-asking rate at the highest control level (z=10), but an adjusted setting allows for near-maximal question-asking rates.}](image4)

BERT's performance significantly deteriorates on the adversarial dataset compared to its performance on the original data. On the original ARCT dataset, BERT achieved a peak performance of $77\%$, which is just three points below the average untrained human baseline [1]. However, when evaluated on the adversarial dataset, BERT's maximum test set accuracy drops to $53\%$, with mean and median scores at $50\%$ [5]. This indicates that the adversarial transformation effectively eliminates the spurious statistical cues that BERT was previously exploiting, leading to a more robust evaluation of its true capabilities.

The adversarial transformation also affects other models similarly, as all models perform randomly on this dataset [3]. This suggests that the issue of spurious cue exploitation is not unique to BERT but is a broader problem in the field of NLP. The adversarial dataset provides a more reliable benchmark for evaluating argument comprehension, as it removes the reliance on these misleading patterns [6].

![{BERT's performance on adversarial dataset}](image1)  
This table illustrates the performance metrics (Mean, Median, and Max) for different models and configurations. BERT's performance on the adversarial dataset shows a significant drop compared to its performance on the original data, highlighting the impact of the adversarial transformation.

In contrast, simpler models like BoV and BiLSTM show less dramatic changes in performance when faced with the adversarial dataset, indicating that they are less reliant on spurious cues [10]. This further supports the conclusion that BERT's high performance on the original dataset was largely due to exploiting these cues rather than genuine understanding of argument comprehension. 

The adversarial transformation thus reveals that BERT has learned nothing meaningful about argument comprehension, as its performance collapses to random levels when the spurious cues are removed [9].

\text{Users not in training set} = \text{Total users} - \text{Users in training set}

$$

Thus, **2,062 users were not included in the training set**.

[1] The example annotation from the text passage illustrates how entities and their relationships are represented in the KGLM framework. It provides a structured breakdown of the text into tokens, mentions, entities, relations, and parent entities, as seen in the annotated table [2]. For instance, the token "Super Mario Land" is identified as an entity and linked to its publication date "04-21-1989" through the relation "pub date." Additionally, it is associated with the genre "platform video game" and the publisher "Nintendo," which is further connected to the platform "Game Boy" via the relation "launch game." 

![{The table shows how entities and their relationships are structured in the example annotation, including tokens, mention types, entities, relations, and parent entities for the text passage about Super Mario Land.}](image2)

[2] In this context, the model dynamically selects entities based on the discourse and generates plausible facts from the knowledge graph. For example, the entity "Nintendo" is rendered as a token because it is related to "Super Mario Land" through the "Publisher" relation. The model also considers multiple plausible reasons for mentioning "Game Boy," such as it being the platform for "Super Mario Land" or manufactured by "Nintendo," even though only the former is more relevant here. 

[4] The process involves selecting a reference to an existing entity, which requires picking a fact to render. As the parent entity of this fact, the model picks "Super Mario Land" and follows the "Publisher" relation to select "Nintendo" as the entity to render. When rendering "Nintendo" as a token, the model has an expanded vocabulary available, containing the standard vocabulary along with all word types in any of the aliases of "Nintendo."

![{The image illustrates the process of generating a token in the middle of a sentence using the KGLM, where the model selects an existing entity, follows a relation, and renders the corresponding entity as a token.}](image4)

[7] The dataset statistics highlight that over 10% of the tokens are considered entity tokens, indicating the importance of incorporating factual knowledge into language models. This underscores the need for models like KGLM to refer to external sources of information, such as Wikidata, to generate accurate and contextually relevant text.

[9] The local knowledge graph is iteratively created by processing the text token by token, adding related entities from Wikidata as candidates. This allows the model to build a dynamic representation of the knowledge graph that evolves as the text is processed, ensuring that new entities and relationships are captured and integrated into the model's understanding.

In summary, entities and their relationships are represented through a structured annotation process that identifies tokens, assigns them to entities, links them via relations, and contextualizes them within the discourse, as demonstrated in the example annotation.

The 'Hard-to-Contrast' querying strategy demonstrates superior performance compared to other strategies in terms of AUC across different numbers of labeled images. As shown in the image, ![{Hard-to-Contrast outperforms other strategies on PathMNIST, BloodMNIST, and Organ AM NIST}](image3), the "hard-to-contrast" strategy consistently leads in AUC scores across various datasets, including PathMNIST, OrganAMNIST, BloodMNIST, and CIFAR-10-LT. This is further supported by text quotes [1] and [8], which report strong positive correlations between AUC scores at 20 and 50 labeled images for the 'Hard-to-Contrast' strategy, with Pearson correlation coefficients of $r=0.92$ and higher performance improvements over other methods.

Moreover, the effectiveness of the 'Hard-to-Contrast' strategy is highlighted in text quote [8], where it outperforms random selection by significant margins on multiple datasets, such as PathMNIST, Organ AM NIST, and BloodMNIST. The implication of this performance is that selecting hard-to-contrast data as the initial query can significantly enhance model performance from the outset, making it a practical and effective solution for the cold start problem in active learning. This is crucial because the initial query choices define the efficacy and efficiency of subsequent learning procedures, as noted in text quote [2].

![{Comparison of AUC scores across different active learning strategies on PathMNIST}](image1) illustrates the consistent superiority of the 'Hard-to-Contrast' strategy, with red lines representing its performance across varying numbers of labeled images. This visual evidence supports the textual findings, emphasizing the importance of choosing hard-to-contrast data for initial queries in active learning to achieve better model performance and efficiency. 

The 'Hard-to-Contrast' querying strategy not only outperforms other methods but also provides a label-free approach, making it particularly suitable for scenarios where ground truth annotations are not readily available. This makes it a robust baseline for initial query selection in active learning.

The proposed system, QAC HECK, is designed with a modular architecture that supports a multi-step fact-checking process. The system comprises five key modules: a Claim Verifier, a Question Generator, a Question-Answering Module, a QA Validator, and a Reasoner. Each of these modules plays a critical role in the verification process, ensuring transparency and accuracy in determining the veracity of a claim.

![{The system's architecture includes five modules, each contributing to the fact-checking process.}](image4)

The Claim Verifier [1] assesses whether the current context is sufficient to validate a claim, leveraging InstructGPT for in-context learning. The Question Generator [5] creates follow-up questions when additional information is needed, again using InstructGPT for generating relevant queries. The Question-Answering Module [4] can be implemented using various models, including FLAN-T5, which is a Seq2Seq model pre-trained on multiple tasks. The QA Validator [1] checks the usefulness of generated (Q, A) pairs, while the Reasoner [1] ultimately determines the final label—Supported or Refuted—based on all collected contexts.

The system also allows for flexibility in implementing the QA module, offering three alternative approaches: the Retriever–Reader model, FLAN-T5, and the GPT Reciter–Reader model [3]. While some modules rely on external APIs like InstructGPT, others, such as the FLAN-T5 model, operate independently based on their internal knowledge [4].

In conclusion, the number of modules implemented with Large Language Models backbone in the proposed system is **five**.

To calculate the average number of instances per article for the Arabic language using the numbers provided in Table 4, we need to use the following data from the text quotes:

- The number of articles for Arabic is mentioned in [9] as **2627**.
- The number of instances for Arabic is mentioned in [3] as **5852**.

Using these values, the average number of instances per article for the Arabic language can be calculated by dividing the total number of instances by the number of articles. 

The calculation is as follows:
$$ \text{Average instances per article} = \frac{\text{Number of instances}}{\text{Number of articles}} = \frac{5852}{2627} \approx 2.23 $$

To determine the percentage of unverified claims out of the total claims for the SE dataset, we refer to the relevant data provided in the text quotes. According to [5], the SemEval-2017 dataset (labeled as SE) includes a breakdown of claims categorized as true, false, and unverified. Specifically, the text mentions that the SE dataset has 272 total claims, with 127 being true claims, 50 being false claims, and 95 being unverified claims.

The percentage of unverified claims can be calculated using the formula:

$$
\text{Percentage of unverified claims} = \left( \frac{\text{Number of unverified claims}}{\text{Total number of claims}} \right) \times 100
$$

Substituting the values from the dataset:

$$

The MMMU benchmark distinguishes itself from other benchmarks by its comprehensive breadth and depth, which are critical for evaluating large multimodal models (LMMs) in a more rigorous and expert-level manner. In terms of **breadth**, MMMU covers a wide range of disciplines, including Art & Design, Business, Science, Health & Medicine, Humanities & Social Science, and Tech & Engineering, spanning 30 subjects and 183 subfields [2]. This extensive coverage is visually represented in image1, where the dataset is highlighted as encompassing diverse image formats such as diagrams, tables, medical images, and music sheets, showcasing its broad applicability across different modalities and domains. ![{comprehensive breadth and depth of MMMU}](image1)

In contrast, many existing benchmarks focus on daily knowledge and common sense, with limited image formats and simpler tasks [5]. For instance, benchmarks like VQA and GQA typically emphasize basic perception without requiring deep domain knowledge or complex reasoning. MMMU, however, introduces a unique challenge by incorporating interleaved text-image inputs, where models must jointly understand both modalities and apply subject-specific knowledge to derive solutions [10]. This is further emphasized in image3, which compares MMMU with other benchmarks and highlights its broader image types and deeper reasoning requirements compared to datasets like VQA and GQA. ![{comparison of MMMU with other benchmarks}](image3)

Regarding **depth**, MMMU requires expert-level reasoning, often involving the application of advanced concepts such as "Fourier Transform" or "Equilibrium Theory" to solve problems [10]. This level of complexity sets it apart from benchmarks that primarily test basic perception or simple reasoning tasks. The dataset also includes a significant proportion of difficult questions, with 45% classified as medium and 27% as hard, as detailed in image2. ![{statistics of question difficulties and formats in MMMU}](image2)

The implications of this breadth and depth are profound for evaluating LMMs. Traditional benchmarks may not fully capture the capabilities of models in handling complex, real-world scenarios that require both multimodal understanding and domain expertise. As shown in image4 and image5, MMMU provides a more accurate assessment of model performance across various disciplines and task types, revealing the strengths and weaknesses of different models in handling expert-level reasoning and perception tasks. ![{model performance comparison on MMMU}](image4) ![{detailed model performance metrics across categories}](image5)

In summary, the MMMU benchmark offers a more comprehensive and challenging evaluation framework for large multimodal models, emphasizing both breadth and depth in assessing their ability to understand and reason across diverse modalities and domains.

The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder plays a crucial role in the system architecture by converting user input into a continuous representation that captures the semantic meaning of the utterance. This encoding is essential for subsequent components such as dialogue state tracking and policy network decision-making. The encoder processes the user's natural language input through a bidirectional Long Short-Term Memory (Bi-LSTM) network, which allows it to consider both past and future context within the utterance, enhancing the model's ability to understand complex user requests [6].

![{The Bi-LSTM Utterance Encoder converts user input into a continuous representation for dialogue understanding}](image1)

In the proposed end-to-end task-oriented dialogue system, this component serves as the initial step in processing user inputs, providing a rich and contextualized vector that informs the rest of the dialogue management pipeline [8]. The encoded user utterance is then combined with the encoding of the previous system action to update the dialogue state, which is critical for maintaining an accurate understanding of the conversation flow and user intent [7].

[1] The model decides which entity to render in the context of 'published by' by first determining the type of mention, $t_t$, which in this case is a reference to an existing entity. This decision is made using a single-layer softmax over $\mathbf{h}_{t,x}$ [1]. Once the type is decided, the model identifies the parent entity, $p_t$, from a pool of local entities, selecting "Super Mario Land" as the parent entity in this instance [4]. Given the parent entity, the model then chooses a relation, $r_t$, which is "PUBLISHER" for this example [3]. Using the parent entity and the selected relation, the model identifies the specific entity to render, $e_t$, which is "Nintendo" in this case, from the local knowledge graph [3]. 

![{The model selects an entity to render based on the parent entity and the chosen relation.}](image3) 

Finally, the model generates the next token, $x_t$ — "Nintendo" — from a distribution that includes both the standard vocabulary and aliases for "Nintendo" [9]. This process ensures that the model accurately renders entities based on the context provided by the sentence and the knowledge graph.

[7] 1. Start at the root layer of the RAPTOR tree. Compute the cosine similarity between the query embedding and the embeddings of all nodes present at this initial layer. 2. Choose the top-  $\cdot k$   nodes based on the highest cosine similarity scores, forming the set  $S_{1}$  .  
[1] 3. Proceed to the child nodes of the elements in set  $S_{1}$  . Compute the cosine similarity between the query vector and the vector embeddings of these child nodes. 4. Select the top  $k$   child nodes with the highest cosine similarity scores to the query, forming the set    $S_{2}$  . 5. Continue this process recursively for  $d$   layers, producing sets  $S_{1},S_{2},.\,.\,.\,,S_{d}$  . 6. Concatenate sets    $S_{1}$   through  $S_{d}$   to assemble the relevant context to the query.

The paper describes a system called QAC HECK, which is designed for multi-hop fact-checking through question-guided reasoning. The system consists of several modules, including a Claim Verifier, Question Generator, Question-Answering (QA) Model, Validator, and Reasoner. The QA module is particularly flexible, offering multiple implementations such as the Retriever–Reader, FLAN-T5, and GPT Reciter–Reader. The proposed DS-DST model determines the matching between candidate values and the dialogue context by leveraging strong interactions between domain-slot pairs and the dialog context. This is achieved through a dual strategy that adapts a single BERT-style reading comprehension model to jointly handle both categorical and non-categorical slots. For categorical slots, the model selects the most plausible values from pre-defined picklists based on contextual representations. For non-categorical slots, it utilizes a two-way linear mapping to find text spans directly from the dialog context. This approach ensures flexibility and effectiveness in handling different types of slots depending on their access level to the ontology or whether their values can be found directly in the dialog context. ![{The DS-DST model architecture shows how the fixed BERT model processes candidate-value lists for categorical slots, while the fine-tuned BERT model handles domain-slot pairs and dialog context through cosine similarity matching.}](image3) The results demonstrate that this method significantly outperforms previous approaches, highlighting the importance of deep interactions between domain-slot and context information.

The image in Figure 11 demonstrates several DNA repair mechanisms that are employed by the cell to correct various types of DNA damage. These mechanisms are essential for maintaining genomic stability and integrity. ![{DNA repair mechanisms in Figure 11}](image3)  

The figure illustrates how different types of DNA damage, such as single-strand breaks, base mismatches, pyrimidine dimers, and double-strand breaks, are repaired through specific pathways. For instance, **Base Excision Repair (BER)** is used to address small lesions like 8-Oxoguanine and single-strand breaks [5]. **Mismatch Repair (MMR)** corrects errors that occur during DNA replication, such as base mismatches and insertions or deletions [6]. **Nucleotide Excision Repair (NER)** is responsible for removing bulky adducts and UV-induced pyrimidine dimers [4]. Lastly, **Recombination Repair** addresses double-strand breaks, which are among the most severe forms of DNA damage, through mechanisms like homologous recombination repair (HR) and non-homologous end-joining (NHEJ) [10].  

These repair mechanisms work in concert with the nuclear DNA repair system to ensure the fidelity of genetic information [8]. The presence of these diverse repair pathways underscores the complexity and importance of DNA repair in preventing mutations and maintaining cellular function.  

The DNA repair mechanisms demonstrated in Figure 11 include Base Excision Repair, Mismatch Repair, Nucleotide Excision Repair, and Recombinational Repair.

In the realm of machine translation evaluation, several metrics have been developed to assess the quality of translated text. Among these, the COMET framework has emerged as a powerful tool for training multilingual and adaptable MT evaluation models [6]. These models are designed to estimate human judgments such as Direct Assessments (DA), Human-mediated Translation Edit Rate (HTER), and metrics compliant with the Multidimensional Quality Metric (MQM) framework [6].

![{COMET models outperform other metrics in multiple language pairs}](image3)

The performance of various metrics across different language pairs is illustrated in Table 2, which highlights the Kendall’s Tau correlations for language pairs where English is the target [3]. This table shows that the DA RR model, part of the COMET framework, consistently outperforms other metrics in five out of seven language pairs, demonstrating strong alignment with human judgments [7].

Moreover, when evaluating the performance of different metrics across a range of top machine translation systems for specific language pairs from English, the line graphs in image2 and image3 illustrate how the COMET models—specifically COMET-RANK, COMET-HTER, and COMET-MQM—maintain high Kendall Tau scores even as the number of evaluated systems decreases [8]. This indicates that these models are robust and effective in ranking translation quality.

![{Kendall Tau scores for different metrics across various language pairs}](image2)

The table in image1 further supports this by presenting the scores achieved by each metric for different language pairs. Notably, the COMET models achieve the highest scores in their respective language pairs, indicating their superior performance compared to traditional metrics like BLEU and BERTScore [4].

![{Evaluation metrics for machine translation systems across various language pairs}](image1)

Across all evaluated language pairs, the COMET models, particularly the DA RR Ranker model, demonstrate consistent superiority over other metrics, often by significant margins [8]. This consistency underscores the effectiveness of the COMET framework in capturing the nuances of translation quality beyond simple lexical similarity.

The metric that consistently performs the best across the language pairs for translation quality evaluation is the COMET framework, specifically the DA RR Ranker model.

The LOGIC-LM model solves a problem by decomposing the logical reasoning task into three key modules: **Problem Formulator**, **Symbolic Reasoner**, and **Result Interpreter**. 

![{The LOGIC-LM model consists of three modules that work together to solve logical reasoning problems}](image5)

In the **Problem Formulator** module, an LLM translates the natural language problem into a symbolic formulation. This involves identifying key entities, facts, and rules from the problem statement and converting them into a structured symbolic representation. For example, a sentence like "If the circuit is complete and the circuit has the light bulb then the light bulb is glowing" is transformed into a logical rule such as `Complete(Circuit, True) ∧ Has(Circuit, LightBulb) → Glowing(LightBulb, True)` [4].

Once the symbolic formulation is generated, it is passed to the **Symbolic Reasoner** module. Here, a deterministic symbolic solver performs inference based on the type of logical problem. For instance, for deductive reasoning, logic programming engines like Pyke are used, while for constraint satisfaction problems, solvers like python-constraint are employed [4]. This stage ensures that the reasoning process is faithful and transparent, leveraging the precision of symbolic logic.

Finally, the **Result Interpreter** module translates the symbolic answer back into natural language, making the solution comprehensible to humans. This step is crucial for delivering a final, interpretable result that aligns with the original problem's context [1].

By integrating these modules, LOGIC-LM effectively combines the natural language understanding capabilities of LLMs with the logical faithfulness of symbolic solvers, leading to more accurate and reliable solutions for complex reasoning tasks.

In the Amazon-beauty dataset, the performance of **NCF+Hard-Coded** is evaluated against other algorithms such as **NCF+Random**, **NCF+Same**, **NCF+Most-Salient**, and **NCF+Soft-labeled**. According to the experimental results, **NCF+Hard-Coded** outperforms **NCF+Most-Salient** in terms of both **NDCG** and **HR**, indicating that utilizing all five personality traits through a fixed, hard-coded vector improves recommendation performance compared to using only the most salient trait [1]. 

![{NCF+Hard-Coded outperforms NCF+Most-Salient in Amazon-beauty}](image3)  
The table in image3 clearly shows that **NCF+Hard-Coded** achieves higher values for both **H@k** and **N@k** metrics on the **Amazon-beauty** dataset, demonstrating its superior performance over other variants.

Additionally, the method described in **NCF+Hard-Coded** involves scaling the raw OCEAN scores to a unit value (here, 100) to form a fixed 5-dimensional vector that represents the user's personality information [2]. This approach ensures consistency during training, which may contribute to better model stability and performance.

In contrast, **NCF+Most-Salient** focuses on using only the most salient personality trait, which, while effective, does not leverage the full spectrum of personality information [3]. The **NCF+Soft-labeled** model, which uses learnable vectors based on a probability distribution derived from softmax, also performs well but slightly less than **NCF+Hard-Coded** in this dataset [7].

Overall, the **NCF+Hard-Coded** model demonstrates the best performance among the tested variants on the **Amazon-beauty** dataset.

[3] The DA RR corpus is derived from human judgements collected by the organizers of the WMT News Translation Shared Task, which are mapped into relative rankings (DA RR). This data forms the basis for evaluating the performance of different MT metrics.

[9] Human judgements of MT quality typically come in the form of segment-level scores, such as DA, MQM, and HTER. For DA, scores are often converted into relative rankings (DA RR) when annotations per segment are limited. This approach helps in comparing the quality of different MT hypotheses.

[7] The results clearly show that for the translation ranking architecture, including the source improves the overall correlation with human judgments. Furthermore, the inclusion of the source exposed the second variant of the model to English embeddings, which likely contributed to its improved performance.

![{Five line graphs illustrate the performance of different MT evaluation metrics over various top MT systems translated into English from different languages, including de-en, fi-en, lt-en, ru-en, and zh-en}](image3)

[4] The MQM corpus is a proprietary internal database of MT-generated translations of customer support chat messages annotated according to specific guidelines. This data covers 12 language pairs, with English always as the source language. Each tuple consists of a source sentence, a human-generated reference, a MT hypothesis, and its MQM score, derived from error annotations by trained annotators.

[5] Historically, metrics for evaluating MT quality have relied on assessing the similarity between an MT hypothesis and a human-generated reference. Traditional metrics focus on lexical-level features such as n-gram matching. Metrics like BLEU and METEOR remain popular due to their efficiency and speed.

[6] The MQM Estimator, trained with only 12K segments, is competitive, highlighting the power of the proposed framework. This suggests that even with limited training data, the model can perform well in certain scenarios.

Step 1) We automatically extract paragraphs which contain a parallel sentence from articles on the same topic in each language (left of Figure 1) [5]. ![{Step 1 of MLQA pipeline}(image4)] 

This initial step involves identifying and extracting relevant content from Wikipedia articles across multiple languages, ensuring that the extracted paragraphs include sentences that have equivalent meanings in different languages. This forms the foundation for subsequent steps in the annotation process, such as question creation and translation. 

The first step is crucial because it ensures that the context used for generating questions and answers is consistent across languages, enabling effective cross-lingual evaluation. ![{Data distribution across languages}(image1)] 

The data collected through this step is then used to build the MLQA benchmark, which includes over 12K instances in English and 5K in each other language, with each instance parallel between 4 languages on average [1]. ![{Number of articles, contexts, and instances per language}(image5)] 

By establishing a robust and parallel dataset, MLQA supports the development of multilingual QA systems and facilitates research into cross-lingual transfer learning. The first step in the MLQA annotation pipeline is to extract parallel sentences and their surrounding contexts from Wikipedia articles.

[1] The performance of BiDAF and FastQA models on the WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets shows distinct differences, as highlighted by various experimental results. On WIKIHOP, BiDAF outperforms FastQA significantly, achieving a performance score of 54.5% on the test set and improving to 59.8% under the test* condition. In contrast, FastQA scores lower, with results of 35.8% (test) and 38.0% (test*). This indicates that BiDAF is more effective in handling the complexities of WIKIHOP, which requires cross-document reasoning and multi-step inference.

![{BiDAF and FastQA performance comparison on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets}(image1)]  
The table in image1 further supports this observation, showing that BiDAF achieves higher scores across both datasets compared to FastQA. For instance, on WIKIHOP, BiDAF reaches 59.8% on the test* condition, while FastQA only manages 38.0%. Similarly, on MEDHOP, BiDAF's performance is 42.9% on the test* condition, whereas FastQA scores 30.6%.

[2] When considering the "gold chain" setup, where models are provided with only the relevant documents leading to the correct answer, BiDAF demonstrates even greater improvements. For example, in the masked gold chain setup on WIKIHOP, BiDAF achieves an impressive 85.7% performance, showcasing its ability to effectively identify the correct answer when presented with minimal distractions. FastQA also improves in this scenario but not as significantly, reaching 70.0% on the test* condition for WIKIHOP.

![{Performance of BiDAF and FastQA in gold chain setup on WIKIHOP and MEDHOP}(image2)]  
Image2 provides additional insights into the performance of these models in different setups. It highlights that BiDAF mask achieves 85.7% on the test* condition for WIKIHOP, indicating strong performance when masking is applied. Conversely, FastQA mask scores 70.0% on the same condition, suggesting that while FastQA benefits from the gold chain setup, it does not match BiDAF's capabilities in this context.

[3] The difference in performance between BiDAF and FastQA can also be attributed to their architectural designs. BiDAF employs iterative conditioning across multiple layers, which enhances its ability to integrate information found across sequences, making it particularly suited for tasks requiring cross-document reasoning. In contrast, FastQA has fewer latent interactions, which may hinder its capacity to handle complex multi-hop reasoning tasks effectively.

[4] Furthermore, the performance of these models varies when certain conditions are altered, such as masking or the presence of irrelevant documents. BiDAF shows a significant drop in performance when documents without candidate mentions are discarded, indicating its reliance on cross-document information. FastQA, on the other hand, exhibits a less pronounced effect, suggesting a different mechanism for information integration.

![{Performance metrics of models under standard and masked conditions}(image4)]  
Image4 illustrates the performance metrics of various models, including BiDAF and FastQA, under standard and masked conditions. It reveals that BiDAF consistently outperforms FastQA, especially in the masked conditions, which require the models to rely solely on the textual context of the candidate expressions.

In conclusion, BiDAF generally outperforms FastQA on both WIKIHOP and MEDHOP datasets, demonstrating superior capabilities in handling complex multi-hop reasoning tasks and integrating information across documents.

[2] Decomposition is more effective than one-step prediction. The **ProgramFC** model, which uses the same **FLAN-T5** model as the sub-task functions, outperforms the baseline of directly verifying claims with **FLAN-T5** on all four datasets. On average, there is a $6.0\%$ improvement in the gold evidence setting and a $4.5\%$ improvement in the open-book setting. This suggests that decomposing a complex claim into simpler steps with a program can facilitate more accurate reasoning. This is especially evident when the required reasoning is complex: there is a $14.9\%$ improvement in the gold evidence setting and a $6.7\%$ improvement in the open-book setting for 4-hop claims.  

[7] To further understand how reasoning programs facilitate fact-checking, we compare the performance of **PROGRAM FC** with **FLAN-T5** using different language model sizes: small, base, large, XL, and XXL. The results are shown in Figure 4 and indicate that program-guided reasoning is particularly effective when the model size is small. As smaller models have less capacity for complex reasoning, the performance of the end-to-end **FLAN-T5** model decreases significantly with decreasing model size. However, this trend is less notable for **PROGRAM FC**. The high-level reasoning plan offered by reasoning programs substantially alleviates the demands on the subsequent sub-task solvers. Our results show that the program-guided model using **FLAN-T5-small** (80M parameters) as sub-task solvers can achieve comparable performance to the $137\times$ larger **FLAN-T5-XXL** (11B) model with end-to-end reasoning for 4-hop claims. ![{ProgramFC outperforms FLAN-T5 across model sizes}](image4)

[1] The filter-then-rerank method, when applied without ensemble, demonstrates notable performance improvements on the 50-shot TACREV dataset. According to the text, this approach consistently achieves an average F1 gain of $2.4\%$ across various IE tasks, including TACREV, with minimal additional latency and cost. This improvement is attributed to the strategic use of SLMs as filters to identify hard samples, which are then reranked by LLMs using appropriate prompting strategies.

![{The filter-then-rerank paradigm effectively combines the strengths of SLMs and LLMs to improve performance on few-shot IE tasks, particularly on challenging datasets like TACREV.}](image2)

[3] A key component of the filter-then-rerank framework is the identification of hard samples, which are reranked by LLMs to enhance overall performance. While the current method uses a simple unsupervised metric (maximum probabilities from SLMs) to assess sample difficulty, future work could explore more advanced difficulty metrics or calibrated SLMs to further improve results.

[6] The filter-then-rerank paradigm involves using SLMs as filters to determine sample difficulty and LLMs as rerankers for hard samples. For the TACREV dataset, the threshold $\tau$ to determine sample difficulty is optimized on the valid set. Hard samples are reranked by LLMs using ICL with 4-shot demos, which significantly improves performance on these challenging cases.

[8] The selective reranking of hard samples in the filter-then-rerank approach leads to substantial performance gains, even though only a minor fraction (0.5%–10%) of samples are deemed hard. On the TACREV dataset, reranking these hard samples results in a significant absolute F1 gain (10%–25%), demonstrating the effectiveness of this strategy.

[9] The filter-then-rerank framework leverages the strengths of both SLMs and LLMs by using SLMs for initial predictions and filtering, while LLMs handle reranking for hard samples. This approach minimizes the extra latency and budget costs associated with calling LLMs, while still achieving consistent F1 improvements. On the TACREV dataset, the method yields an average F1 gain of $2.4\%$, showcasing its effectiveness in enhancing few-shot IE tasks.

![{Performance comparison of different methods on the TACREV dataset, showing that the filter-then-rerank approach outperforms previous state-of-the-art methods.}](image3)

[10] The filter-then-rerank paradigm reframes prompts as multiple-choice questions (MCQ), making it easier for LLMs to process and rerank candidate labels. This format reduces the label scope significantly, allowing LLMs to focus on sample-level decisions rather than sentence-level entity/event identification. As a result, the method is more likely to elicit the full potential of LLMs, leading to improved performance on few-shot IE tasks like TACREV.

[4] The filter-then-rerank paradigm converts few-shot IE tasks into multiple-choice questions, as demonstrated in examples for the FewNERD, TACREV, and ACE05 datasets. These examples highlight how the method structures prompts and utilizes demonstrations to guide LLMs during reranking, ensuring accurate and efficient processing of hard samples.

[5] Table 3 shows that the filter-then-rerank method consistently improves performance across three datasets and nine settings. For instance, with InstructGPT, reranking provides an average F1 gain of $2.4\%$ without SLM ensemble. This confirms the effectiveness of LLM reranking and highlights its gains being different and almost orthogonal to the SLM ensemble, further validating the success of the approach on the TACREV dataset.

![{Financial and time cost comparison of different approaches on the TACREV dataset, showing that the filter-then-rerank method offers a balance between performance and efficiency.}](image4)

In conclusion, the filter-then-rerank method (w.o. ensemble) achieves a performance improvement on the 50-shot TACREV dataset with an average F1 gain of $2.4\%$.
